눅 1:33 And he will reign over Israel① forever; his Kingdom will never end!" / ①Greek over the house of Jacob
눅 1:34 Mary asked the angel, "But how can this happen? I am a virgin."
눅 1:35 The angel replied, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God.
눅 1:36 What's more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she's now in her sixth month.
눅 1:37 For nothing is impossible with God①." / ①Some manuscripts read For the word of God will never fail
눅 1:38 Mary responded, "I am the Lord's servant. May everything you have said about me come true." And then the angel left her.
눅 1:39 A few days later Mary hurried to the hill country of Judea, to the town
눅 1:40 where Zechariah lived. She entered the house and greeted Elizabeth.
눅 1:41 At the sound of Mary's greeting, Elizabeth's child leaped within her, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
눅 1:42 Elizabeth gave a glad cry and exclaimed to Mary, "God has blessed you above all women, and your child is blessed.
눅 1:43 Why am I so honored, that the mother of my Lord should visit me?
눅 1:44 When I heard your greeting, the baby in my womb jumped for joy.
눅 1:45 You are blessed because you believed that the Lord would do what he said."
눅 1:46 Mary responded, "Oh, how my soul praises the Lord.
눅 1:47 How my spirit rejoices in God my Savior!
눅 1:48 For he took notice of his lowly servant girl, and from now on all generations will call me blessed.
눅 1:49 For the Mighty One is holy, and he has done great things for me.
눅 1:50 He shows mercy from generation to generation to all who fear him.
눅 1:51 His mighty arm has done tremendous things! He has scattered the proud and haughty ones.
눅 1:52 He has brought down princes from their thrones and exalted the humble.
눅 1:53 He has filled the hungry with good things and sent the rich away with empty hands.
눅 1:54 He has helped his servant Israel and remembered to be merciful.
눅 1:55 For he made this promise to our ancestors, to Abraham and his children forever."
눅 1:56 Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months and then went back to her own home.
눅 1:57 When it was time for Elizabeth's baby to be born, she gave birth to a son.
눅 1:58 And when her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had been very merciful to her, everyone rejoiced with her.
눅 1:59 When the baby was eight days old, they all came for the circumcision ceremony. They wanted to name him Zechariah, after his father.
눅 1:60 But Elizabeth said, "No! His name is John!"
눅 1:61 "What?" they exclaimed. "There is no one in all your family by that name."
눅 1:62 So they used gestures to ask the baby's father what he wanted to name him.
눅 1:63 He motioned for a writing tablet, and to everyone's surprise he wrote, "His name is John."
눅 1:64 Instantly Zechariah could speak again, and he began praising God.
눅 1:65 Awe fell upon the whole neighborhood, and the news of what had happened spread throughout the Judean hills.
눅 1:66 Everyone who heard about it reflected on these events and asked, "What will this child turn out to be?" For the hand of the Lord was surely upon him in a special way.
눅 1:67 Then his father, Zechariah, was filled with the Holy Spirit and gave this prophecy.
눅 1:68 "Praise the Lord, the God of Israel, because he has visited and redeemed his people.
눅 1:69 He has sent us a mighty Savior① from the royal line of his servant David, / ①Greek has raised up a horn of salvation for us
눅 1:70 just as he promised through his holy prophets long ago.
눅 1:71 Now we will be saved from our enemies and from all who hate us.
눅 1:72 He has been merciful to our ancestors by remembering his sacred covenant?
눅 1:73 the covenant he swore with an oath to our ancestor Abraham.
눅 1:74 We have been rescued from our enemies so we can serve God without fear,
눅 1:75 in holiness and righteousness for as long as we live.
눅 1:76 "And you, my little son, will be called the prophet of the Most High, because you will prepare the way for the Lord.
눅 1:77 You will tell his people how to find salvation through forgiveness of their sins. 
눅 1:78 Because of God's tender mercy, the morning light from heaven is about to break upon us①, / ①Or the Morning Light from Heaven is about to visit us
눅 1:79 to give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, and to guide us to the path of peace."
눅 1:80 John grew up and became strong in spirit. And he lived in the wilderness until he began his public ministry to Israel.
눅 2:1 At that time the Roman emperor, Augustus, decreed that a census should be taken throughout the Roman Empire.
눅 2:2 (This was the first census taken when Quirinius was governor of Syria)
눅 2:3 All returned to their own ancestral towns to register for this census.
눅 2:4 And because Joseph was a descendant of King David, he had to go to Bethlehem in Judea, David's ancient home. He traveled there from the village of Nazareth in Galilee.
눅 2:5 He took with him Mary, his fiancee, who was now obviously pregnant.
눅 2:6 And while they were there, the time came for her baby to be born.
눅 2:7 She gave birth to her first child, a son. She wrapped him snugly in strips of cloth and laid him in a manger, because there was no lodging available for them.
눅 2:8 That night there were shepherds staying in the fields nearby, guarding their flocks of sheep.
눅 2:9 Suddenly, an angel of the Lord appeared among them, and the radiance of the Lord's glory surrounded them. They were terrified,
눅 2:10 but the angel reassured them. "Don't be afraid!" he said. "I bring you good news that will bring great joy to all people.
눅 2:11 The Savior?yes, the Messiah, the Lord?has been born today in Bethlehem, the city of David!
눅 2:12 And you will recognize him by this sign： You will find a baby wrapped snugly in strips of cloth, lying in a manger."
눅 2:13 Suddenly, the angel was joined by a vast host of others?the armies of heaven?praising God and saying,
눅 2:14 "Glory to God in highest heaven, and peace on earth to those with whom God is pleased."
눅 2:15 When the angels had returned to heaven, the shepherds said to each other, "Let's go to Bethlehem! Let's see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about."
눅 2:16 They hurried to the village and found Mary and Joseph. And there was the baby, lying in the manger.
눅 2:17 After seeing him, the shepherds told everyone what had happened and what the angel had said to them about this child.
눅 2:18 All who heard the shepherds' story were astonished,
눅 2:19 but Mary kept all these things in her heart and thought about them often.
눅 2:20 The shepherds went back to their flocks, glorifying and praising God for all they had heard and seen. It was just as the angel had told them.
눅 2:21 Eight days later, when the baby was circumcised, he was named Jesus, the name given him by the angel even before he was conceived.
눅 2:22 Then it was time for their purification offering, as required by the law of Moses after the birth of a child; so his parents took him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord.
눅 2:23 The law of the Lord says, "If a woman's first child is a boy, he must be dedicated to the LORD."① / ①Exod 13.2
눅 2:24 So they offered the sacrifice required in the law of the Lord?"either a pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons."① / ①Lev 12.8
눅 2:25 At that time there was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon. He was righteous and devout and was eagerly waiting for the Messiah to come and rescue Israel. The Holy Spirit was upon him
눅 2:26 and had revealed to him that he would not die until he had seen the Lord's Messiah.
눅 2:27 That day the Spirit led him to the Temple. So when Mary and Joseph came to present the baby Jesus to the Lord as the law required,
눅 2:28 Simeon was there. He took the child in his arms and praised God, saying,
눅 2:29 "Sovereign Lord, now let your servant die in peace, as you have promised.
눅 2:30 I have seen your salvation,
눅 2:31 which you have prepared for all people.
눅 2:32 He is a light to reveal God to the nations, and he is the glory of your people Israel!"
눅 2:33 Jesus' parents were amazed at what was being said about him.
눅 2:34 Then Simeon blessed them, and he said to Mary, the baby's mother, "This child is destined to cause many in Israel to fall, but he will be a joy to many others. He has been sent as a sign from God, but many will oppose him.
눅 2:35 As a result, the deepest thoughts of many hearts will be revealed. And a sword will pierce your very soul."
눅 2:36 Anna, a prophet, was also there in the Temple. She was the daughter of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher, and she was very old. Her husband died when they had been married only seven years.
눅 2:37 Then she lived as a widow to the age of eighty-four①. She never left the Temple but stayed there day and night, worshiping God with fasting and prayer. / ①Or She had been a widow for eighty-four years
눅 2:38 She came along just as Simeon was talking with Mary and Joseph, and she began praising God. She talked about the child to everyone who had been waiting expectantly for God to rescue Jerusalem.
눅 2:39 When Jesus' parents had fulfilled all the requirements of the law of the Lord, they returned home to Nazareth in Galilee.
눅 2:40 There the child grew up healthy and strong. He was filled with wisdom, and God's favor was on him.
눅 2:41 Every year Jesus' parents went to Jerusalem for the Passover festival.
눅 2:42 When Jesus was twelve years old, they attended the festival as usual.
눅 2:43 After the celebration was over, they started home to Nazareth, but Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem. His parents didn't miss him at first,
눅 2:44 because they assumed he was among the other travelers. But when he didn't show up that evening, they started looking for him among their relatives and friends.
눅 2:45 When they couldn't find him, they went back to Jerusalem to search for him there.
눅 2:46 Three days later they finally discovered him in the Temple, sitting among the religious teachers, listening to them and asking questions.
눅 2:47 All who heard him were amazed at his understanding and his answers.
눅 2:48 His parents didn't know what to think. "Son," his mother said to him, "why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been frantic, searching for you everywhere."
눅 2:49 "But why did you need to search?" he asked. "Didn't you know that I must be in my Father's house?"① / ①Or "Didn't you realize that I should be involved with my Father's affairs?"
눅 2:50 But they didn't understand what he meant.
눅 2:51 Then he returned to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them. And his mother stored all these things in her heart.
눅 2:52 Jesus grew in wisdom and in stature and in favor with God and all the people.
눅 3:1 It was now the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius, the Roman emperor. Pontius Pilate was governor over Judea; Herod Antipas was ruler① over Galilee; his brother Philip was ruler② over Iturea and Traconitis; Lysanias was ruler③ over Abilene. / ①Greek Herod was tetrarch. Herod Antipas was a son of King Herod ②Greek tetrarch ③Greek tetrarch
눅 3:2 Annas and Caiaphas were the high priests. At this time a message from God came to John son of Zechariah, who was living in the wilderness.
눅 3:3 Then John went from place to place on both sides of the Jordan River, preaching that people should be baptized to show that they had repented of their sins and turned to God to be forgiven.
눅 3:4 Isaiah had spoken of John when he said, "He is a voice shouting in the wilderness, `Prepare the way for the LORD's coming! Clear the road for him!
눅 3:5 The valleys will be filled, and the mountains and hills made level. The curves will be straightened, and the rough places made smooth.
눅 3:6 And then all people will see the salvation sent from God.'"① / ①Isa 40.3-5 (Greek version)
눅 3:7 When the crowds came to John for baptism, he said, "You brood of snakes! Who warned you to flee God's coming wrath?
눅 3:8 Prove by the way you live that you have repented of your sins and turned to God. Don't just say to each other, `We're safe, for we are descendants of Abraham.' That means nothing, for I tell you, God can create children of Abraham from these very stones.
눅 3:9 Even now the ax of God's judgment is poised, ready to sever the roots of the trees. Yes, every tree that does not produce good fruit will be chopped down and thrown into the fire."
눅 3:10 The crowds asked, "What should we do?"
눅 3:11 John replied, "If you have two shirts, give one to the poor. If you have food, share it with those who are hungry."
눅 3:12 Even corrupt tax collectors came to be baptized and asked, "Teacher, what should we do?"
눅 3:13 He replied, "Collect no more taxes than the government requires."
눅 3:14 "What should we do?" asked some soldiers. John replied, "Don't extort money or make false accusations. And be content with your pay."
눅 3:15 Everyone was expecting the Messiah to come soon, and they were eager to know whether John might be the Messiah.
눅 3:16 John answered their questions by saying, "I baptize you with① water; but someone is coming soon who is greater than I am?so much greater that I'm not even worthy to be his slave and untie the straps of his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire②. / ①Or in ②Or in the Holy Spirit and in fire
눅 3:17 He is ready to separate the chaff from the wheat with his winnowing fork. Then he will clean up the threshing area, gathering the wheat into his barn but burning the chaff with never-ending fire."
눅 3:18 John used many such warnings as he announced the Good News to the people.
눅 3:19 John also publicly criticized Herod Antipas, the ruler of Galilee①, for marrying Herodias, his brother's wife, and for many other wrongs he had done. / ①Greek Herod the tetrarch
눅 3:20 So Herod put John in prison, adding this sin to his many others.
눅 3:21 One day when the crowds were being baptized, Jesus himself was baptized. As he was praying, the heavens opened,
눅 3:22 and the Holy Spirit, in bodily form, descended on him like a dove. And a voice from heaven said, "You are my dearly loved Son, and you bring me great joy①." / ①Some manuscripts read my Son, and today I have become your Father
눅 3:23 Jesus was about thirty years old when he began his public ministry. Jesus was known as the son of Joseph. Joseph was the son of Heli.
눅 3:24 Heli was the son of Matthat. Matthat was the son of Levi. Levi was the son of Melki. Melki was the son of Jannai. Jannai was the son of Joseph.
눅 3:25 Joseph was the son of Mattathias. Mattathias was the son of Amos. Amos was the son of Nahum. Nahum was the son of Esli. Esli was the son of Naggai.
눅 3:26 Naggai was the son of Maath. Maath was the son of Mattathias. Mattathias was the son of Semein. Semein was the son of Josech. Josech was the son of Joda.
눅 3:27 Joda was the son of Joanan. Joanan was the son of Rhesa. Rhesa was the son of Zerubbabel. Zerubbabel was the son of Shealtiel. Shealtiel was the son of Neri.
눅 3:28 Neri was the son of Melki. Melki was the son of Addi. Addi was the son of Cosam. Cosam was the son of Elmadam. Elmadam was the son of Er.
눅 3:29 Er was the son of Joshua. Joshua was the son of Eliezer. Eliezer was the son of Jorim. Jorim was the son of Matthat. Matthat was the son of Levi.
눅 3:30 Levi was the son of Simeon. Simeon was the son of Judah. Judah was the son of Joseph. Joseph was the son of Jonam. Jonam was the son of Eliakim.
눅 3:31 Eliakim was the son of Melea. Melea was the son of Menna. Menna was the son of Mattatha. Mattatha was the son of Nathan. Nathan was the son of David.
눅 3:32 David was the son of Jesse. Jesse was the son of Obed. Obed was the son of Boaz. Boaz was the son of Salmon①. Salmon was the son of Nahshon. / ①Greek Sala, a variant spelling of Salmon; See Ruth 4.22
눅 3:33 Nahshon was the son of Amminadab. Amminadab was the son of Admin. Admin was the son of Arni①. Arni was the son of Hezron. Hezron was the son of Perez. Perez was the son of Judah. / ①Some manuscripts read Amminadab was the son of Aram. Arni and Aram are alternate spellings of Ram. See 1 Chr 2.9-10
눅 3:34 Judah was the son of Jacob. Jacob was the son of Isaac. Isaac was the son of Abraham. Abraham was the son of Terah. Terah was the son of Nahor.
눅 3:35 Nahor was the son of Serug. Serug was the son of Reu. Reu was the son of Peleg. Peleg was the son of Eber. Eber was the son of Shelah.
눅 3:36 Shelah was the son of Cainan. Cainan was the son of Arphaxad. Arphaxad was the son of Shem. Shem was the son of Noah. Noah was the son of Lamech.
눅 3:37 Lamech was the son of Methuselah. Methuselah was the son of Enoch. Enoch was the son of Jared. Jared was the son of Mahalalel. Mahalalel was the son of Kenan.
눅 3:38 Kenan was the son of Enosh①. Enosh was the son of Seth. Seth was the son of Adam. Adam was the son of God. / ①Greek Enos, a variant spelling of Enosh; See Gen 5.6
눅 4:1 Then Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan River. He was led by the Spirit in the wilderness①, / ①Some manuscripts read into the wilderness
눅 4:2 where he was tempted by the devil for forty days. Jesus ate nothing all that time and became very hungry.
눅 4:3 Then the devil said to him, "If you are the Son of God, tell this stone to become a loaf of bread."
눅 4:4 But Jesus told him, "No! The Scriptures say, `People do not live by bread alone.'①" / ①Deut 8.3
눅 4:5 Then the devil took him up and revealed to him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
눅 4:6 "I will give you the glory of these kingdoms and authority over them," the devil said, "because they are mine to give to anyone I please.
눅 4:7 I will give it all to you if you will worship me."
눅 4:8 Jesus replied, "The Scriptures say, `You must worship the LORD your God and serve only him.'①" / ①Deut 6.13
눅 4:9 Then the devil took him to Jerusalem, to the highest point of the Temple, and said, "If you are the Son of God, jump off!
눅 4:10 For the Scriptures say, `He will order his angels to protect and guard you.
눅 4:11 And they will hold you up with their hands so you won't even hurt your foot on a stone.'①" / ①Ps 91.11-12
눅 4:12 Jesus responded, "The Scriptures also say, `You must not test the LORD your God.'①" / ①Deut 6.16
눅 4:13 When the devil had finished tempting Jesus, he left him until the next opportunity came.
눅 4:14 Then Jesus returned to Galilee, filled with the Holy Spirit's power. Reports about him spread quickly through the whole region.
눅 4:15 He taught regularly in their synagogues and was praised by everyone.
눅 4:16 When he came to the village of Nazareth, his boyhood home, he went as usual to the synagogue on the Sabbath and stood up to read the Scriptures.
눅 4:17 The scroll of Isaiah the prophet was handed to him. He unrolled the scroll and found the place where this was written.
눅 4:18 "The Spirit of the LORD is upon me, for he has anointed me to bring Good News to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim that captives will be released, that the blind will see, that the oppressed will be set free,
눅 4:19 and that the time of the LORD's favor has come①." / ①Or and to proclaim the acceptable year of the LORD. Isa 61.1-2 (Greek version); 58.6
눅 4:20 He rolled up the scroll, handed it back to the attendant, and sat down. All eyes in the synagogue looked at him intently.
눅 4:21 Then he began to speak to them. "The Scripture you've just heard has been fulfilled this very day!"
눅 4:22 Everyone spoke well of him and was amazed by the gracious words that came from his lips. "How can this be?" they asked. "Isn't this Joseph's son?"
눅 4:23 Then he said, "You will undoubtedly quote me this proverb： `Physician, heal yourself'?meaning, `Do miracles here in your hometown like those you did in Capernaum.'
눅 4:24 But I tell you the truth, no prophet is accepted in his own hometown.
눅 4:25 "Certainly there were many needy widows in Israel in Elijah's time, when the heavens were closed for three and a half years, and a severe famine devastated the land.
눅 4:26 Yet Elijah was not sent to any of them. He was sent instead to a foreigner?a widow of Zarephath in the land of Sidon.
눅 4:27 And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha, but the only one healed was Naaman, a Syrian."
눅 4:28 When they heard this, the people in the synagogue were furious.
눅 4:29 Jumping up, they mobbed him and forced him to the edge of the hill on which the town was built. They intended to push him over the cliff,
눅 4:30 but he passed right through the crowd and went on his way.
눅 4:31 Then Jesus went to Capernaum, a town in Galilee, and taught there in the synagogue every Sabbath day.
눅 4:32 There, too, the people were amazed at his teaching, for he spoke with authority.
눅 4:33 Once when he was in the synagogue, a man possessed by a demon - an evil① spirit - began shouting at Jesus, / ①Greek unclean; also in 4.36
눅 4:34 "Go away! Why are you interfering with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are?the Holy One sent from God!"
눅 4:35 Jesus cut him short. "Be quiet! Come out of the man," he ordered. At that, the demon threw the man to the floor as the crowd watched; then it came out of him without hurting him further.
눅 4:36 Amazed, the people exclaimed, "What authority and power this man's words possess! Even evil spirits obey him, and they flee at his command!"
눅 4:37 The news about Jesus spread through every village in the entire region.
눅 4:38 After leaving the synagogue that day, Jesus went to Simon's home, where he found Simon's mother-in-law very sick with a high fever. "Please heal her," everyone begged.
눅 4:39 Standing at her bedside, he rebuked the fever, and it left her. And she got up at once and prepared a meal for them.
눅 4:40 As the sun went down that evening, people throughout the village brought sick family members to Jesus. No matter what their diseases were, the touch of his hand healed every one.
눅 4:41 Many were possessed by demons; and the demons came out at his command, shouting, "You are the Son of God!" But because they knew he was the Messiah, he rebuked them and refused to let them speak.
눅 4:42 Early the next morning Jesus went out to an isolated place. The crowds searched everywhere for him, and when they finally found him, they begged him not to leave them.
눅 4:43 But he replied, "I must preach the Good News of the Kingdom of God in other towns, too, because that is why I was sent."
눅 4:44 So he continued to travel around, preaching in synagogues throughout Judea①. / ①Some manuscripts read Galilee
눅 5:1 One day as Jesus was preaching on the shore of the Sea of Galilee①, great crowds pressed in on him to listen to the word of God. / ①Greek Lake Gennesaret, another name for the Sea of Galilee
눅 5:2 He noticed two empty boats at the water's edge, for the fishermen had left them and were washing their nets.
눅 5:3 Stepping into one of the boats, Jesus asked Simon①, its owner, to push it out into the water. So he sat in the boat and taught the crowds from there. / ①Simon is called "Peter" in 6.14 and thereafter
눅 5:4 When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, "Now go out where it is deeper, and let down your nets to catch some fish."
눅 5:5 "Master," Simon replied, "we worked hard all last night and didn't catch a thing. But if you say so, I'll let the nets down again."
눅 5:6 And this time their nets were so full of fish they began to tear!
눅 5:7 A shout for help brought their partners in the other boat, and soon both boats were filled with fish and on the verge of sinking.
눅 5:8 When Simon Peter realized what had happened, he fell to his knees before Jesus and said, "Oh, Lord, please leave me?I'm too much of a sinner to be around you."
눅 5:9 For he was awestruck by the number of fish they had caught, as were the others with him.
눅 5:10 His partners, James and John, the sons of Zebedee, were also amazed. Jesus replied to Simon, "Don't be afraid! From now on you'll be fishing for people!"
눅 5:11 And as soon as they landed, they left everything and followed Jesus.
눅 5:12 In one of the villages, Jesus met a man with an advanced case of leprosy. When the man saw Jesus, he bowed with his face to the ground, begging to be healed. "Lord," he said, "if you are willing, you can heal me and make me clean."
눅 5:13 Jesus reached out and touched him. "I am willing," he said. "Be healed!" And instantly the leprosy disappeared.
눅 5:14 Then Jesus instructed him not to tell anyone what had happened. He said, "Go to the priest and let him examine you. Take along the offering required in the law of Moses for those who have been healed of leprosy①. This will be a public testimony that you have been cleansed." / ①See Lev 14.2-32
눅 5:15 But despite Jesus' instructions, the report of his power spread even faster, and vast crowds came to hear him preach and to be healed of their diseases.
눅 5:16 But Jesus often withdrew to the wilderness for prayer.
눅 5:17 One day while Jesus was teaching, some Pharisees and teachers of religious law were sitting nearby. ① And the Lord's healing power was strongly with Jesus. / ①It seemed that these men showed up from every village in all Galilee and Judea, as well as from Jerusalem
눅 5:18 Some men came carrying a paralyzed man on a sleeping mat. They tried to take him inside to Jesus,
눅 5:19 but they couldn't reach him because of the crowd. So they went up to the roof and took off some tiles. Then they lowered the sick man on his mat down into the crowd, right in front of Jesus.
눅 5:20 Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the man, "Young man, your sins are forgiven."
눅 5:21 But the Pharisees and teachers of religious law said to themselves, "Who does he think he is? That's blasphemy! Only God can forgive sins!"
눅 5:22 Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he asked them, "Why do you question this in your hearts?
눅 5:23 Is it easier to say `Your sins are forgiven,' or `Stand up and walk'?
눅 5:24 So I will prove to you that the Son of Man① has the authority on earth to forgive sins." Then Jesus turned to the paralyzed man and said, "Stand up, pick up your mat, and go home!" / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 5:25 And immediately, as everyone watched, the man jumped up, picked up his mat, and went home praising God.
눅 5:26 Everyone was gripped with great wonder and awe, and they praised God, exclaiming, "We have seen amazing things today!"
눅 5:27 Later, as Jesus left the town, he saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at his tax collector's booth. "Follow me and be my disciple," Jesus said to him.
눅 5:28 So Levi got up, left everything, and followed him.
눅 5:29 Later, Levi held a banquet in his home with Jesus as the guest of honor. Many of Levi's fellow tax collectors and other guests also ate with them.
눅 5:30 But the Pharisees and their teachers of religious law complained bitterly to Jesus' disciples, "Why do you eat and drink with such scum?①" / ①Greek with tax collectors and sinners?
눅 5:31 Jesus answered them, "Healthy people don't need a doctor?sick people do.
눅 5:32 I have come to call not those who think they are righteous, but those who know they are sinners and need to repent."
눅 5:33 One day some people said to Jesus, "John the Baptist's disciples fast and pray regularly, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees. Why are your disciples always eating and drinking?"
눅 5:34 Jesus responded, "Do wedding guests fast while celebrating with the groom? Of course not.
눅 5:35 But someday the groom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast."
눅 5:36 Then Jesus gave them this illustration： "No one tears a piece of cloth from a new garment and uses it to patch an old garment. For then the new garment would be ruined, and the new patch wouldn't even match the old garment.
눅 5:37 "And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. For the new wine would burst the wineskins, spilling the wine and ruining the skins.
눅 5:38 New wine must be stored in new wineskins.
눅 5:39 But no one who drinks the old wine seems to want the new wine. `The old is just fine,' they say."
눅 6:1 One Sabbath day as Jesus was walking through some grainfields, his disciples broke off heads of grain, rubbed off the husks in their hands, and ate the grain.
눅 6:2 But some Pharisees said, "Why are you breaking the law by harvesting grain on the Sabbath?"
눅 6:3 Jesus replied, "Haven't you read in the Scriptures what David did when he and his companions were hungry?
눅 6:4 He went into the house of God and broke the law by eating the sacred loaves of bread that only the priests can eat. He also gave some to his companions."
눅 6:5 And Jesus added, "The Son of Man① is Lord, even over the Sabbath." / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 6:6 On another Sabbath day, a man with a deformed right hand was in the synagogue while Jesus was teaching.
눅 6:7 The teachers of religious law and the Pharisees watched Jesus closely. If he healed the man's hand, they planned to accuse him of working on the Sabbath.
눅 6:8 But Jesus knew their thoughts. He said to the man with the deformed hand, "Come and stand in front of everyone." So the man came forward.
눅 6:9 Then Jesus said to his critics, "I have a question for you. Does the law permit good deeds on the Sabbath, or is it a day for doing evil? Is this a day to save life or to destroy it?"
눅 6:10 He looked around at them one by one and then said to the man, "Hold out your hand." So the man held out his hand, and it was restored!
눅 6:11 At this, the enemies of Jesus were wild with rage and began to discuss what to do with him.
눅 6:12 One day soon afterward Jesus went up on a mountain to pray, and he prayed to God all night.
눅 6:13 At daybreak he called together all of his disciples and chose twelve of them to be apostles. Here are their names.
눅 6:14 Simon (whom he named Peter), Andrew (Peter's brother), James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
눅 6:15 Matthew, Thomas, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon (who was called the zealot),
눅 6:16 Judas (son of James), Judas Iscariot (who later betrayed him). 
눅 6:17 When they came down from the mountain, the disciples stood with Jesus on a large, level area, surrounded by many of his followers and by the crowds. There were people from all over Judea and from Jerusalem and from as far north as the seacoasts of Tyre and Sidon.
눅 6:18 They had come to hear him and to be healed of their diseases; and those troubled by evil① spirits were healed. / ①Greek unclean
눅 6:19 Everyone tried to touch him, because healing power went out from him, and he healed everyone.
눅 6:20 Then Jesus turned to his disciples and said, "God blesses you who are poor, for the Kingdom of God is yours.
눅 6:21 God blesses you who are hungry now, for you will be satisfied. God blesses you who weep now, for in due time you will laugh.
눅 6:22 What blessings await you when people hate you and exclude you and mock you and curse you as evil because you follow the Son of Man.
눅 6:23 When that happens, be happy! Yes, leap for joy! For a great reward awaits you in heaven. And remember, their ancestors treated the ancient prophets that same way.
눅 6:24 "What sorrow awaits you who are rich, for you have your only happiness now.
눅 6:25 What sorrow awaits you who are fat and prosperous now, for a time of awful hunger awaits you. What sorrow awaits you who laugh now, for your laughing will turn to mourning and sorrow.
눅 6:26 What sorrow awaits you who are praised by the crowds, for their ancestors also praised false prophets.
눅 6:27 "But to you who are willing to listen, I say, love your enemies! Do good to those who hate you.
눅 6:28 Bless those who curse you. Pray for those who hurt you.
눅 6:29 If someone slaps you on one cheek, offer the other cheek also. If someone demands your coat, offer your shirt also.
눅 6:30 Give to anyone who asks; and when things are taken away from you, don't try to get them back.
눅 6:31 Do to others as you would like them to do to you.
눅 6:32 "If you love only those who love you, why should you get credit for that? Even sinners love those who love them!
눅 6:33 And if you do good only to those who do good to you, why should you get credit? Even sinners do that much!
눅 6:34 And if you lend money only to those who can repay you, why should you get credit? Even sinners will lend to other sinners for a full return.
눅 6:35 "Love your enemies! Do good to them. Lend to them without expecting to be repaid. Then your reward from heaven will be very great, and you will truly be acting as children of the Most High, for he is kind to those who are unthankful and wicked.
눅 6:36 You must be compassionate, just as your Father is compassionate.
눅 6:37 "Do not judge others, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn others, or it will all come back against you. Forgive others, and you will be forgiven.
눅 6:38 Give, and you will receive. Your gift will return to you in full?pressed down, shaken together to make room for more, running over, and poured into your lap. The amount you give will determine the amount you get back①." / ①Or The measure you give will be the measure you get back
눅 6:39 Then Jesus gave the following illustration： "Can one blind person lead another? Won't they both fall into a ditch?
눅 6:40 Students① are not greater than their teacher. But the student who is fully trained will become like the teacher. / ①Or Disciples
눅 6:41 "And why worry about a speck in your friend's eye① when you have a log in your own? / ①Greek your brother's eye; also in 6.42
눅 6:42 How can you think of saying, `Friend①, let me help you get rid of that speck in your eye,' when you can't see past the log in your own eye? Hypocrite! First get rid of the log in your own eye; then you will see well enough to deal with the speck in your friend's eye. / ①Greek Brother
눅 6:43 "A good tree can't produce bad fruit, and a bad tree can't produce good fruit.
눅 6:44 A tree is identified by its fruit. Figs are never gathered from thornbushes, and grapes are not picked from bramble bushes.
눅 6:45 A good person produces good things from the treasury of a good heart, and an evil person produces evil things from the treasury of an evil heart. What you say flows from what is in your heart.
눅 6:46 "So why do you keep calling me `Lord, Lord!' when you don't do what I say?
눅 6:47 I will show you what it's like when someone comes to me, listens to my teaching, and then follows it.
눅 6:48 It is like a person building a house who digs deep and lays the foundation on solid rock. When the floodwaters rise and break against that house, it stands firm because it is well built.
눅 6:49 But anyone who hears and doesn't obey is like a person who builds a house without a foundation. When the floods sweep down against that house, it will collapse into a heap of ruins."
눅 7:1 When Jesus had finished saying all this to the people, he returned to Capernaum.
눅 7:2 At that time the highly valued slave of a Roman officer① was sick and near death. / ①Greek a centurion; similarly in 7.6
눅 7:3 When the officer heard about Jesus, he sent some respected Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his slave.
눅 7:4 So they earnestly begged Jesus to help the man. "If anyone deserves your help, he does," they said,
눅 7:5 "for he loves the Jewish people and even built a synagogue for us."
눅 7:6 So Jesus went with them. But just before they arrived at the house, the officer sent some friends to say, "Lord, don't trouble yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of such an honor.
눅 7:7 I am not even worthy to come and meet you. Just say the word from where you are, and my servant will be healed.
눅 7:8 I know this because I am under the authority of my superior officers, and I have authority over my soldiers. I only need to say, `Go,' and they go, or `Come,' and they come. And if I say to my slaves, `Do this,' they do it."
눅 7:9 When Jesus heard this, he was amazed. Turning to the crowd that was following him, he said, "I tell you, I haven't seen faith like this in all Israel!"
눅 7:10 And when the officer's friends returned to his house, they found the slave completely healed.
눅 7:11 Soon afterward Jesus went with his disciples to the village of Nain, and a large crowd followed him.
눅 7:12 A funeral procession was coming out as he approached the village gate. The young man who had died was a widow's only son, and a large crowd from the village was with her.
눅 7:13 When the Lord saw her, his heart overflowed with compassion. "Don't cry!" he said.
눅 7:14 Then he walked over to the coffin and touched it, and the bearers stopped. "Young man," he said, "I tell you, get up."
눅 7:15 Then the dead boy sat up and began to talk! And Jesus gave him back to his mother.
눅 7:16 Great fear swept the crowd, and they praised God, saying, "A mighty prophet has risen among us," and "God has visited his people today."
눅 7:17 And the news about Jesus spread throughout Judea and the surrounding countryside.
눅 7:18 The disciples of John the Baptist told John about everything Jesus was doing. So John called for two of his disciples,
눅 7:19 and he sent them to the Lord to ask him, "Are you the Messiah we've been expecting①, or should we keep looking for someone else?" / ①Greek Are you the one who is coming? Also in 7.20
눅 7:20 John's two disciples found Jesus and said to him, "John the Baptist sent us to ask, `Are you the Messiah we've been expecting, or should we keep looking for someone else?'"
눅 7:21 At that very time, Jesus cured many people of their diseases, illnesses, and evil spirits, and he restored sight to many who were blind.
눅 7:22 Then he told John's disciples, "Go back to John and tell him what you have seen and heard?the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cured, the deaf hear, the dead are raised to life, and the Good News is being preached to the poor.
눅 7:23 And tell him, `God blesses those who do not turn away because of me①.'" / ①Or who are not offended by me
눅 7:24 After John's disciples left, Jesus began talking about him to the crowds. "What kind of man did you go into the wilderness to see? Was he a weak reed, swayed by every breath of wind?
눅 7:25 Or were you expecting to see a man dressed in expensive clothes? No, people who wear beautiful clothes and live in luxury are found in palaces.
눅 7:26 Were you looking for a prophet? Yes, and he is more than a prophet.
눅 7:27 John is the man to whom the Scriptures refer when they say, `Look, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, and he will prepare your way before you.'① / ①Mal 3.1
눅 7:28 I tell you, of all who have ever lived, none is greater than John. Yet even the least person in the Kingdom of God is greater than he is!"
눅 7:29 When they heard this, all the people?even the tax collectors?agreed that God's way was right①, for they had been baptized by John. / ①Or praised God for his justice
눅 7:30 But the Pharisees and experts in religious law rejected God's plan for them, for they had refused John's baptism.
눅 7:31 "To what can I compare the people of this generation?" Jesus asked. "How can I describe them?
눅 7:32 They are like children playing a game in the public square. They complain to their friends, `We played wedding songs, and you didn't dance, so we played funeral songs, and you didn't weep.'
눅 7:33 For John the Baptist didn't spend his time eating bread or drinking wine, and you say, `He's possessed by a demon.'
눅 7:34 The Son of Man①, on the other hand, feasts and drinks, and you say, `He's a glutton and a drunkard, and a friend of tax collectors and other sinners!' / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 7:35 But wisdom is shown to be right by the lives of those who follow it①." / ①Or But wisdom is justified by all her children
눅 7:36 One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to have dinner with him, so Jesus went to his home and sat down to eat①. / ①Or and reclined
눅 7:37 When a certain immoral woman from that city heard he was eating there, she brought a beautiful alabaster jar filled with expensive perfume.
눅 7:38 Then she knelt behind him at his feet, weeping. Her tears fell on his feet, and she wiped them off with her hair. Then she kept kissing his feet and putting perfume on them.
눅 7:39 When the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, "If this man were a prophet, he would know what kind of woman is touching him. She's a sinner!"
눅 7:40 Then Jesus answered his thoughts. "Simon," he said to the Pharisee, "I have something to say to you." "Go ahead, Teacher," Simon replied.
눅 7:41 Then Jesus told him this story： "A man loaned money to two people?500 pieces of silver① to one and 50 pieces to the other. / ①Greek 500 denarii. A denarius was equivalent to a laborer's full day's wage
눅 7:42 But neither of them could repay him, so he kindly forgave them both, canceling their debts. Who do you suppose loved him more after that?"
눅 7:43 Simon answered, "I suppose the one for whom he canceled the larger debt." "That's right," Jesus said.
눅 7:44 Then he turned to the woman and said to Simon, "Look at this woman kneeling here. When I entered your home, you didn't offer me water to wash the dust from my feet, but she has washed them with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
눅 7:45 You didn't greet me with a kiss, but from the time I first came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
눅 7:46 You neglected the courtesy of olive oil to anoint my head, but she has anointed my feet with rare perfume.
눅 7:47 "I tell you, her sins?and they are many?have been forgiven, so she has shown me much love. But a person who is forgiven little shows only little love."
눅 7:48 Then Jesus said to the woman, "Your sins are forgiven."
눅 7:49 The men at the table said among themselves, "Who is this man, that he goes around forgiving sins?"
눅 7:50 And Jesus said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you; go in peace."
눅 8:1 Soon afterward Jesus began a tour of the nearby towns and villages, preaching and announcing the Good News about the Kingdom of God. He took his twelve disciples with him,
눅 8:2 along with some women who had been cured of evil spirits and diseases. Among them were Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons;
눅 8:3 Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's business manager; Susanna; and many others who were contributing their own resources to support Jesus and his disciples.
눅 8:4 One day Jesus told a story in the form of a parable to a large crowd that had gathered from many towns to hear him.
눅 8:5 "A farmer went out to plant his seed. As he scattered it across his field, some seed fell on a footpath, where it was stepped on, and the birds ate it.
눅 8:6 Other seed fell among rocks. It began to grow, but the plant soon wilted and died for lack of moisture.
눅 8:7 Other seed fell among thorns that grew up with it and choked out the tender plants.
눅 8:8 Still other seed fell on fertile soil. This seed grew and produced a crop that was a hundred times as much as had been planted!" When he had said this, he called out, "Anyone with ears to hear should listen and understand."
눅 8:9 His disciples asked him what this parable meant.
눅 8:10 He replied, "You are permitted to understand the secrets① of the Kingdom of God. But I use parables to teach the others so that the Scriptures might be fulfilled： `When they look, they won't really see. When they hear, they won't understand.'② / ①Greek mysteries ②Isa 6.9 (Greek version)
눅 8:11 "This is the meaning of the parable： The seed is God's word.
눅 8:12 The seeds that fell on the footpath represent those who hear the message, only to have the devil come and take it away from their hearts and prevent them from believing and being saved.
눅 8:13 The seeds on the rocky soil represent those who hear the message and receive it with joy. But since they don't have deep roots, they believe for a while, then they fall away when they face temptation.
눅 8:14 The seeds that fell among the thorns represent those who hear the message, but all too quickly the message is crowded out by the cares and riches and pleasures of this life. And so they never grow into maturity.
눅 8:15 And the seeds that fell on the good soil represent honest, good-hearted people who hear God's word, cling to it, and patiently produce a huge harvest.
눅 8:16 "No one lights a lamp and then covers it with a bowl or hides it under a bed. A lamp is placed on a stand, where its light can be seen by all who enter the house.
눅 8:17 For all that is secret will eventually be brought into the open, and everything that is concealed will be brought to light and made known to all.
눅 8:18 "So pay attention to how you hear. To those who listen to my teaching, more understanding will be given. But for those who are not listening, even what they think they understand will be taken away from them."
눅 8:19 Then Jesus' mother and brothers came to see him, but they couldn't get to him because of the crowd.
눅 8:20 Someone told Jesus, "Your mother and your brothers are outside, and they want to see you."
눅 8:21 Jesus replied, "My mother and my brothers are all those who hear God's word and obey it."
눅 8:22 One day Jesus said to his disciples, "Let's cross to the other side of the lake." So they got into a boat and started out.
눅 8:23 As they sailed across, Jesus settled down for a nap. But soon a fierce storm came down on the lake. The boat was filling with water, and they were in real danger.
눅 8:24 The disciples went and woke him up, shouting, "Master, Master, we're going to drown!" When Jesus woke up, he rebuked the wind and the raging waves. Suddenly the storm stopped and all was calm!
눅 8:25 Then he asked them, "Where is your faith?" The disciples were terrified and amazed. "Who is this man?" they asked each other. "When he gives a command, even the wind and waves obey him!"
눅 8:26 So they arrived in the region of the Gerasenes①, across the lake from Galilee. / ①Other manuscripts read Gadarenes; still others read Gergesenes; also in 8.37. See Matt 8.28; Mark 5.1
눅 8:27 As Jesus was climbing out of the boat, a man who was possessed by demons came out to meet him. For a long time he had been homeless and naked, living in a cemetery outside the town.
눅 8:28 As soon as he saw Jesus, he shrieked and fell down in front of him. Then he screamed, "Why are you interfering with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? Please, I beg you, don't torture me!"
눅 8:29 For Jesus had already commanded the evil① spirit to come out of him. This spirit had often taken control of the man. Even when he was placed under guard and put in chains and shackles, he simply broke them and rushed out into the wilderness, completely under the demon's power. / ①Greek unclean
눅 8:30 Jesus demanded, "What is your name?" "Legion," he replied, for he was filled with many demons.
눅 8:31 The demons kept begging Jesus not to send them into the bottomless pit①. / ①Or the abyss, or the underworld
눅 8:32 There happened to be a large herd of pigs feeding on the hillside nearby, and the demons begged him to let them enter into the pigs. So Jesus gave them permission.
눅 8:33 Then the demons came out of the man and entered the pigs, and the entire herd plunged down the steep hillside into the lake and drowned.
눅 8:34 When the herdsmen saw it, they fled to the nearby town and the surrounding countryside, spreading the news as they ran.
눅 8:35 People rushed out to see what had happened. A crowd soon gathered around Jesus, and they saw the man who had been freed from the demons. He was sitting at Jesus' feet, fully clothed and perfectly sane, and they were all afraid.
눅 8:36 Then those who had seen what happened told the others how the demon-possessed man had been healed.
눅 8:37 And all the people in the region of the Gerasenes begged Jesus to go away and leave them alone, for a great wave of fear swept over them. So Jesus returned to the boat and left, crossing back to the other side of the lake.
눅 8:38 The man who had been freed from the demons begged to go with him. But Jesus sent him home, saying,
눅 8:39 "No, go back to your family, and tell them everything God has done for you." So he went all through the town proclaiming the great things Jesus had done for him.
눅 8:40 On the other side of the lake the crowds welcomed Jesus, because they had been waiting for him.
눅 8:41 Then a man named Jairus, a leader of the local synagogue, came and fell at Jesus' feet, pleading with him to come home with him.
눅 8:42 His only daughter①, who was about twelve years old, was dying. As Jesus went with him, he was surrounded by the crowds. / ①Or His only child, a daughter
눅 8:43 A woman in the crowd had suffered for twelve years with constant bleeding①, and she could find no cure. / ①Some manuscripts add having spent everything she had on doctors
눅 8:44 Coming up behind Jesus, she touched the fringe of his robe. Immediately, the bleeding stopped.
눅 8:45 "Who touched me?" Jesus asked. Everyone denied it, and Peter said, "Master, this whole crowd is pressing up against you."
눅 8:46 But Jesus said, "Someone deliberately touched me, for I felt healing power go out from me."
눅 8:47 When the woman realized that she could not stay hidden, she began to tremble and fell to her knees in front of him. The whole crowd heard her explain why she had touched him and that she had been immediately healed.
눅 8:48 "Daughter," he said to her, "your faith has made you well. Go in peace."
눅 8:49 While he was still speaking to her, a messenger arrived from the home of Jairus, the leader of the synagogue. He told him, "Your daughter is dead. There's no use troubling the Teacher now."
눅 8:50 But when Jesus heard what had happened, he said to Jairus, "Don't be afraid. Just have faith, and she will be healed."
눅 8:51 When they arrived at the house, Jesus wouldn't let anyone go in with him except Peter, John, James, and the little girl's father and mother.
눅 8:52 The house was filled with people weeping and wailing, but he said, "Stop the weeping! She isn't dead; she's only asleep."
눅 8:53 But the crowd laughed at him because they all knew she had died.
눅 8:54 Then Jesus took her by the hand and said in a loud voice, "My child, get up!"
눅 8:55 And at that moment her life① returned, and she immediately stood up! Then Jesus told them to give her something to eat. / ①Or her spirit
눅 8:56 Her parents were overwhelmed, but Jesus insisted that they not tell anyone what had happened.
눅 9:1 One day Jesus called together his twelve disciples① and gave them power and authority to cast out all demons and to heal all diseases. / ①Greek the Twelve; other manuscripts read the twelve apostles
눅 9:2 Then he sent them out to tell everyone about the Kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
눅 9:3 "Take nothing for your journey," he instructed them. "Don't take a walking stick, a traveler's bag, food, money①, or even a change of clothes. / ①Or silver coins
눅 9:4 Wherever you go, stay in the same house until you leave town.
눅 9:5 And if a town refuses to welcome you, shake its dust from your feet as you leave to show that you have abandoned those people to their fate."
눅 9:6 So they began their circuit of the villages, preaching the Good News and healing the sick.
눅 9:7 When Herod Antipas, the ruler of Galilee①, heard about everything Jesus was doing, he was puzzled. Some were saying that John the Baptist had been raised from the dead. / ①Greek Herod the tetrarch. Herod Antipas was a son of King Herod and was ruler over Galilee
눅 9:8 Others thought Jesus was Elijah or one of the other prophets risen from the dead.
눅 9:9 "I beheaded John," Herod said, "so who is this man about whom I hear such stories?" And he kept trying to see him.
눅 9:10 When the apostles returned, they told Jesus everything they had done. Then he slipped quietly away with them toward the town of Bethsaida.
눅 9:11 But the crowds found out where he was going, and they followed him. He welcomed them and taught them about the Kingdom of God, and he healed those who were sick.
눅 9:12 Late in the afternoon the twelve disciples came to him and said, "Send the crowds away to the nearby villages and farms, so they can find food and lodging for the night. There is nothing to eat here in this remote place."
눅 9:13 But Jesus said, "You feed them." "But we have only five loaves of bread and two fish," they answered. "Or are you expecting us to go and buy enough food for this whole crowd?"
눅 9:14 For there were about 5,000 men there. Jesus replied, "Tell them to sit down in groups of about fifty each."
눅 9:15 So the people all sat down.
눅 9:16 Jesus took the five loaves and two fish, looked up toward heaven, and blessed them. Then, breaking the loaves into pieces, he kept giving the bread and fish to the disciples so they could distribute it to the people.
눅 9:17 They all ate as much as they wanted, and afterward, the disciples picked up twelve baskets of leftovers!
눅 9:18 One day Jesus left the crowds to pray alone. Only his disciples were with him, and he asked them, "Who do people say I am?"
눅 9:19 "Well," they replied, "some say John the Baptist, some say Elijah, and others say you are one of the other ancient prophets risen from the dead."
눅 9:20 Then he asked them, "But who do you say I am?" Peter replied, "You are the Messiah① sent from God!" / ①Or the Christ. Messiah (a Hebrew term) and Christ (a Greek term) both mean "the anointed one."
눅 9:21 Jesus warned his disciples not to tell anyone who he was.
눅 9:22 "The Son of Man① must suffer many terrible things," he said. "He will be rejected by the elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of religious law. He will be killed, but on the third day he will be raised from the dead." / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 9:23 Then he said to the crowd, "If any of you wants to be my follower, you must turn from your selfish ways, take up your cross daily, and follow me.
눅 9:24 If you try to hang on to your life, you will lose it. But if you give up your life for my sake, you will save it.
눅 9:25 And what do you benefit if you gain the whole world but are yourself lost or destroyed?
눅 9:26 If anyone is ashamed of me and my message, the Son of Man will be ashamed of that person when he returns in his glory and in the glory of the Father and the holy angels.
눅 9:27 I tell you the truth, some standing here right now will not die before they see the Kingdom of God."
눅 9:28 About eight days later Jesus took Peter, John, and James up on a mountain to pray.
눅 9:29 And as he was praying, the appearance of his face was transformed, and his clothes became dazzling white.
눅 9:30 Suddenly, two men, Moses and Elijah, appeared and began talking with Jesus.
눅 9:31 They were glorious to see. And they were speaking about his exodus from this world, which was about to be fulfilled in Jerusalem.
눅 9:32 Peter and the others had fallen asleep. When they woke up, they saw Jesus' glory and the two men standing with him.
눅 9:33 As Moses and Elijah were starting to leave, Peter, not even knowing what he was saying, blurted out, "Master, it's wonderful for us to be here! Let's make three shelters as memorials① - one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah." / ①Greek three tabernacles
눅 9:34 But even as he was saying this, a cloud overshadowed them, and terror gripped them as the cloud covered them.
눅 9:35 Then a voice from the cloud said, "This is my Son, my Chosen One①. Listen to him." / ①Some manuscripts read This is my dearly loved Son
눅 9:36 When the voice finished, Jesus was there alone. They didn't tell anyone at that time what they had seen.
눅 9:37 The next day, after they had come down the mountain, a large crowd met Jesus.
눅 9:38 A man in the crowd called out to him, "Teacher, I beg you to look at my son, my only child.
눅 9:39 An evil spirit keeps seizing him, making him scream. It throws him into convulsions so that he foams at the mouth. It batters him and hardly ever leaves him alone.
눅 9:40 I begged your disciples to cast out the spirit, but they couldn't do it."
눅 9:41 Jesus said, "You faithless and corrupt people! How long must I be with you and put up with you?" Then he said to the man, "Bring your son here."
눅 9:42 As the boy came forward, the demon knocked him to the ground and threw him into a violent convulsion. But Jesus rebuked the evil① spirit and healed the boy. Then he gave him back to his father. / ①Greek unclean
눅 9:43 Awe gripped the people as they saw this majestic display of God's power. While everyone was marveling at everything he was doing, Jesus said to his disciples,
눅 9:44 "Listen to me and remember what I say. The Son of Man is going to be betrayed into the hands of his enemies."
눅 9:45 But they didn't know what he meant. Its significance was hidden from them, so they couldn't understand it, and they were afraid to ask him about it.
눅 9:46 Then his disciples began arguing about which of them was the greatest.
눅 9:47 But Jesus knew their thoughts, so he brought a little child to his side.
눅 9:48 Then he said to them, "Anyone who welcomes a little child like this on my behalf① welcomes me, and anyone who welcomes me also welcomes my Father who sent me. Whoever is the least among you is the greatest." / ①Greek in my name
눅 9:49 John said to Jesus, "Master, we saw someone using your name to cast out demons, but we told him to stop because he isn't in our group."
눅 9:50 But Jesus said, "Don't stop him! Anyone who is not against you is for you."
눅 9:51 As the time drew near for him to ascend to heaven, Jesus resolutely set out for Jerusalem.
눅 9:52 He sent messengers ahead to a Samaritan village to prepare for his arrival.
눅 9:53 But the people of the village did not welcome Jesus because he was on his way to Jerusalem.
눅 9:54 When James and John saw this, they said to Jesus, "Lord, should we call down fire from heaven to burn them up①?" / ①Some manuscripts add as Elijah did
눅 9:55 But Jesus turned and rebuked them①. / ①Some manuscripts add an expanded conclusion to verse 55 and an additional sentence in verse 56： And he said, "You don't realize what your hearts are like. 56 For the Son of Man has not come to destroy people's lives, but to save them."
눅 9:56 So they went on to another village.
눅 9:57 As they were walking along, someone said to Jesus, "I will follow you wherever you go."
눅 9:58 But Jesus replied, "Foxes have dens to live in, and birds have nests, but the Son of Man has no place even to lay his head."
눅 9:59 He said to another person, "Come, follow me." The man agreed, but he said, "Lord, first let me return home and bury my father."
눅 9:60 But Jesus told him, "Let the spiritually dead bury their own dead!① Your duty is to go and preach about the Kingdom of God." / ①Greek Let the dead bury their own dead
눅 9:61 Another said, "Yes, Lord, I will follow you, but first let me say good-bye to my family."
눅 9:62 But Jesus told him, "Anyone who puts a hand to the plow and then looks back is not fit for the Kingdom of God."
눅 10:1 The Lord now chose seventy-two① other disciples and sent them ahead in pairs to all the towns and places he planned to visit. / ①Some manuscripts read seventy; also in 10.17
눅 10:2 These were his instructions to them： "The harvest is great, but the workers are few. So pray to the Lord who is in charge of the harvest; ask him to send more workers into his fields.
눅 10:3 Now go, and remember that I am sending you out as lambs among wolves.
눅 10:4 Don't take any money with you, nor a traveler's bag, nor an extra pair of sandals. And don't stop to greet anyone on the road.
눅 10:5 "Whenever you enter someone's home, first say, `May God's peace be on this house.'
눅 10:6 If those who live there are peaceful, the blessing will stand; if they are not, the blessing will return to you.
눅 10:7 Don't move around from home to home. Stay in one place, eating and drinking what they provide. Don't hesitate to accept hospitality, because those who work deserve their pay.
눅 10:8 "If you enter a town and it welcomes you, eat whatever is set before you.
눅 10:9 Heal the sick, and tell them, `The Kingdom of God is near you now.'
눅 10:10 But if a town refuses to welcome you, go out into its streets and say,
눅 10:11 `We wipe even the dust of your town from our feet to show that we have abandoned you to your fate. And know this?the Kingdom of God is near!'
눅 10:12 I assure you, even wicked Sodom will be better off than such a town on judgment day.
눅 10:13 "What sorrow awaits you, Korazin and Bethsaida! For if the miracles I did in you had been done in wicked Tyre and Sidon, their people would have repented of their sins long ago, clothing themselves in burlap and throwing ashes on their heads to show their remorse.
눅 10:14 Yes, Tyre and Sidon will be better off on judgment day than you.
눅 10:15 And you people of Capernaum, will you be honored in heaven? No, you will go down to the place of the dead①." / ①Greek to Hades
눅 10:16 Then he said to the disciples, "Anyone who accepts your message is also accepting me. And anyone who rejects you is rejecting me. And anyone who rejects me is rejecting God, who sent me."
눅 10:17 When the seventy-two disciples returned, they joyfully reported to him, "Lord, even the demons obey us when we use your name!"
눅 10:18 "Yes," he told them, "I saw Satan fall from heaven like lightning!
눅 10:19 Look, I have given you authority over all the power of the enemy, and you can walk among snakes and scorpions and crush them. Nothing will injure you.
눅 10:20 But don't rejoice because evil spirits obey you; rejoice because your names are registered in heaven."
눅 10:21 At that same time Jesus was filled with the joy of the Holy Spirit, and he said, "O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, thank you for hiding these things from those who think themselves wise and clever, and for revealing them to the childlike. Yes, Father, it pleased you to do it this way.
눅 10:22 "My Father has entrusted everything to me. No one truly knows the Son except the Father, and no one truly knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him."
눅 10:23 Then when they were alone, he turned to the disciples and said, "Blessed are the eyes that see what you have seen.
눅 10:24 I tell you, many prophets and kings longed to see what you see, but they didn't see it. And they longed to hear what you hear, but they didn't hear it."
눅 10:25 One day an expert in religious law stood up to test Jesus by asking him this question： "Teacher, what should I do to inherit eternal life?"
눅 10:26 Jesus replied, "What does the law of Moses say? How do you read it?"
눅 10:27 The man answered, "`You must love the LORD your God with all your heart, all your soul, all your strength, and all your mind.' And, `Love your neighbor as yourself.'"① / ①Deut 6.5; Lev 19.18
눅 10:28 "Right!" Jesus told him. "Do this and you will live!"
눅 10:29 The man wanted to justify his actions, so he asked Jesus, "And who is my neighbor?"
눅 10:30 Jesus replied with a story： "A Jewish man was traveling on a trip from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he was attacked by bandits. They stripped him of his clothes, beat him up, and left him half dead beside the road.
눅 10:31 "By chance a priest came along. But when he saw the man lying there, he crossed to the other side of the road and passed him by.
눅 10:32 A Temple assistant① walked over and looked at him lying there, but he also passed by on the other side. / ①Greek A Levite
눅 10:33 "Then a despised Samaritan came along, and when he saw the man, he felt compassion for him.
눅 10:34 Going over to him, the Samaritan soothed his wounds with olive oil and wine and bandaged them. Then he put the man on his own donkey and took him to an inn, where he took care of him.
눅 10:35 The next day he handed the innkeeper two silver coins①, telling him, `Take care of this man. If his bill runs higher than this, I'll pay you the next time I'm here.' / ①Greek two denarii. A denarius was equivalent to a laborer's full day's wage

눅 10:36 "Now which of these three would you say was a neighbor to the man who was attacked by bandits?" Jesus asked.
눅 10:37 The man replied, "The one who showed him mercy." Then Jesus said, "Yes, now go and do the same."
눅 10:38 As Jesus and the disciples continued on their way to Jerusalem, they came to a certain village where a woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
눅 10:39 Her sister, Mary, sat at the Lord's feet, listening to what he taught.
눅 10:40 But Martha was distracted by the big dinner she was preparing. She came to Jesus and said, "Lord, doesn't it seem unfair to you that my sister just sits here while I do all the work? Tell her to come and help me."
눅 10:41 But the Lord said to her, "My dear Martha, you are worried and upset over all these details!
눅 10:42 There is only one thing worth being concerned about. Mary has discovered it, and it will not be taken away from her."
눅 11:1 Once Jesus was in a certain place praying. As he finished, one of his disciples came to him and said, "Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his disciples."
눅 11:2 Jesus said, "This is how you should pray①. "Father, may your name be kept holy. May your Kingdom come soon. / ①Some manuscripts add additional phrases from the Lord's Prayer as it reads in Matt 6.9-13
눅 11:3 Give us each day the food we need①, / ①Or Give us each day our food for the day; or Give us each day our food for tomorrow
눅 11:4 and forgive us our sins, as we forgive those who sin against us. And don't let us yield to temptation①." / ①Or And keep us from being tested
눅 11:5 Then, teaching them more about prayer, he used this story： "Suppose you went to a friend's house at midnight, wanting to borrow three loaves of bread. You say to him,
눅 11:6 `A friend of mine has just arrived for a visit, and I have nothing for him to eat.'
눅 11:7 And suppose he calls out from his bedroom, `Don't bother me. The door is locked for the night, and my family and I are all in bed. I can't help you.'
눅 11:8 But I tell you this?though he won't do it for friendship's sake, if you keep knocking long enough, he will get up and give you whatever you need because of your shameless persistence①. / ①Or in order to avoid shame, or so his reputation won't be damaged
눅 11:9 "And so I tell you, keep on asking, and you will receive what you ask for. Keep on seeking, and you will find. Keep on knocking, and the door will be opened to you.
눅 11:10 For everyone who asks, receives. Everyone who seeks, finds. And to everyone who knocks, the door will be opened.
눅 11:11 "You fathers?if your children ask① for a fish, do you give them a snake instead? / ①Some manuscripts add for bread, do you give them a stone? Or [if they ask]
눅 11:12 Or if they ask for an egg, do you give them a scorpion? Of course not!
눅 11:13 So if you sinful people know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him."
눅 11:14 One day Jesus cast out a demon from a man who couldn't speak, and when the demon was gone, the man began to speak. The crowds were amazed,
눅 11:15 but some of them said, "No wonder he can cast out demons. He gets his power from Satan①, the prince of demons." / ①Greek Beelzeboul; also in 11.18, 19. Other manuscripts read Beezeboul; Latin version reads Beelzebub
눅 11:16 Others, trying to test Jesus, demanded that he show them a miraculous sign from heaven to prove his authority.
눅 11:17 He knew their thoughts, so he said, "Any kingdom divided by civil war is doomed. A family splintered by feuding will fall apart.
눅 11:18 You say I am empowered by Satan. But if Satan is divided and fighting against himself, how can his kingdom survive?
눅 11:19 And if I am empowered by Satan, what about your own exorcists? They cast out demons, too, so they will condemn you for what you have said.
눅 11:20 But if I am casting out demons by the power of God①, then the Kingdom of God has arrived among you. / ①Greek by the finger of God
눅 11:21 For when a strong man like Satan is fully armed and guards his palace, his possessions are safe?
눅 11:22 until someone even stronger attacks and overpowers him, strips him of his weapons, and carries off his belongings.
눅 11:23 "Anyone who isn't with me opposes me, and anyone who isn't working with me is actually working against me.
눅 11:24 "When an evil① spirit leaves a person, it goes into the desert, searching for rest. But when it finds none, it says, `I will return to the person I came from.' / ①Greek unclean
눅 11:25 So it returns and finds that its former home is all swept and in order.
눅 11:26 Then the spirit finds seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they all enter the person and live there. And so that person is worse off than before."
눅 11:27 As he was speaking, a woman in the crowd called out, "God bless your mother?the womb from which you came, and the breasts that nursed you!"
눅 11:28 Jesus replied, "But even more blessed are all who hear the word of God and put it into practice."
눅 11:29 As the crowd pressed in on Jesus, he said, "This evil generation keeps asking me to show them a miraculous sign. But the only sign I will give them is the sign of Jonah.
눅 11:30 What happened to him was a sign to the people of Nineveh that God had sent him. What happens to the Son of Man① will be a sign to these people that he was sent by God. / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 11:31 "The queen of Sheba① will stand up against this generation on judgment day and condemn it, for she came from a distant land to hear the wisdom of Solomon. Now someone greater than Solomon is here?but you refuse to listen. / ①Greek The queen of the south
눅 11:32 The people of Nineveh will also stand up against this generation on judgment day and condemn it, for they repented of their sins at the preaching of Jonah. Now someone greater than Jonah is here?but you refuse to repent.
눅 11:33 "No one lights a lamp and then hides it or puts it under a basket①. Instead, a lamp is placed on a stand, where its light can be seen by all who enter the house. / ①Some manuscripts omit or puts it under a basket
눅 11:34 "Your eye is a lamp that provides light for your body. When your eye is good, your whole body is filled with light. But when it is bad, your body is filled with darkness.
눅 11:35 Make sure that the light you think you have is not actually darkness.
눅 11:36 If you are filled with light, with no dark corners, then your whole life will be radiant, as though a floodlight were filling you with light."
눅 11:37 As Jesus was speaking, one of the Pharisees invited him home for a meal. So he went in and took his place at the table①. / ①Or and reclined
눅 11:38 His host was amazed to see that he sat down to eat without first performing the hand-washing ceremony required by Jewish custom.
눅 11:39 Then the Lord said to him, "You Pharisees are so careful to clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside you are filthy?full of greed and wickedness!
눅 11:40 Fools! Didn't God make the inside as well as the outside?
눅 11:41 So clean the inside by giving gifts to the poor, and you will be clean all over.
눅 11:42 "What sorrow awaits you Pharisees! For you are careful to tithe even the tiniest income from your herb gardens①, but you ignore justice and the love of God. You should tithe, yes, but do not neglect the more important things. / ①Greek tithe the mint, the rue, and every herb
눅 11:43 "What sorrow awaits you Pharisees! For you love to sit in the seats of honor in the synagogues and receive respectful greetings as you walk in the marketplaces.
눅 11:44 Yes, what sorrow awaits you! For you are like hidden graves in a field. People walk over them without knowing the corruption they are stepping on."
눅 11:45 "Teacher," said an expert in religious law, "you have insulted us, too, in what you just said."
눅 11:46 "Yes," said Jesus, "what sorrow also awaits you experts in religious law! For you crush people with unbearable religious demands, and you never lift a finger to ease the burden.
눅 11:47 What sorrow awaits you! For you build monuments for the prophets your own ancestors killed long ago.
눅 11:48 But in fact, you stand as witnesses who agree with what your ancestors did. They killed the prophets, and you join in their crime by building the monuments!
눅 11:49 This is what God in his wisdom said about you①. `I will send prophets and apostles to them, but they will kill some and persecute the others.' / ①Greek Therefore, the wisdom of God said
눅 11:50 "As a result, this generation will be held responsible for the murder of all God's prophets from the creation of the world?
눅 11:51 from the murder of Abel to the murder of Zechariah, who was killed between the altar and the sanctuary. Yes, it will certainly be charged against this generation.
눅 11:52 "What sorrow awaits you experts in religious law! For you remove the key to knowledge from the people. You don't enter the Kingdom yourselves, and you prevent others from entering."
눅 11:53 As Jesus was leaving, the teachers of religious law and the Pharisees became hostile and tried to provoke him with many questions.
눅 11:54 They wanted to trap him into saying something they could use against him.
눅 12:1 Meanwhile, the crowds grew until thousands were milling about and stepping on each other. Jesus turned first to his disciples and warned them, "Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees?their hypocrisy.
눅 12:2 The time is coming when everything that is covered up will be revealed, and all that is secret will be made known to all.
눅 12:3 Whatever you have said in the dark will be heard in the light, and what you have whispered behind closed doors will be shouted from the housetops for all to hear!
눅 12:4 "Dear friends, don't be afraid of those who want to kill your body; they cannot do any more to you after that.
눅 12:5 But I'll tell you whom to fear. Fear God, who has the power to kill you and then throw you into hell①. Yes, he's the one to fear. / ①Greek Gehenna
눅 12:6 "What is the price of five sparrows?two copper coins①? Yet God does not forget a single one of them. / ①Greek two assaria [Roman coins equal to - of a denarius]
눅 12:7 And the very hairs on your head are all numbered. So don't be afraid; you are more valuable to God than a whole flock of sparrows.
눅 12:8 "I tell you the truth, everyone who acknowledges me publicly here on earth, the Son of Man① will also acknowledge in the presence of God's angels. / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 12:9 But anyone who denies me here on earth will be denied before God's angels.
눅 12:10 Anyone who speaks against the Son of Man can be forgiven, but anyone who blasphemes the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
눅 12:11 "And when you are brought to trial in the synagogues and before rulers and authorities, don't worry about how to defend yourself or what to say,
눅 12:12 for the Holy Spirit will teach you at that time what needs to be said."
눅 12:13 Then someone called from the crowd, "Teacher, please tell my brother to divide our father's estate with me."
눅 12:14 Jesus replied, "Friend, who made me a judge over you to decide such things as that?"
눅 12:15 Then he said, "Beware! Guard against every kind of greed. Life is not measured by how much you own."
눅 12:16 Then he told them a story： "A rich man had a fertile farm that produced fine crops.
눅 12:17 He said to himself, `What should I do? I don't have room for all my crops.'
눅 12:18 Then he said, `I know! I'll tear down my barns and build bigger ones. Then I'll have room enough to store all my wheat and other goods.
눅 12:19 And I'll sit back and say to myself, "My friend, you have enough stored away for years to come. Now take it easy! Eat, drink, and be merry!"'
눅 12:20 "But God said to him, `You fool! You will die this very night. Then who will get everything you worked for?'
눅 12:21 "Yes, a person is a fool to store up earthly wealth but not have a rich relationship with God."
눅 12:22 Then, turning to his disciples, Jesus said, "That is why I tell you not to worry about everyday life?whether you have enough food to eat or enough clothes to wear.
눅 12:23 For life is more than food, and your body more than clothing.
눅 12:24 Look at the ravens. They don't plant or harvest or store food in barns, for God feeds them. And you are far more valuable to him than any birds!
눅 12:25 Can all your worries add a single moment to your life?
눅 12:26 And if worry can't accomplish a little thing like that, what's the use of worrying over bigger things?
눅 12:27 "Look at the lilies and how they grow. They don't work or make their clothing, yet Solomon in all his glory was not dressed as beautifully as they are.
눅 12:28 And if God cares so wonderfully for flowers that are here today and thrown into the fire tomorrow, he will certainly care for you. Why do you have so little faith?
눅 12:29 "And don't be concerned about what to eat and what to drink. Don't worry about such things.
눅 12:30 These things dominate the thoughts of unbelievers all over the world, but your Father already knows your needs.
눅 12:31 Seek the Kingdom of God above all else, and he will give you everything you need.
눅 12:32 "So don't be afraid, little flock. For it gives your Father great happiness to give you the Kingdom.
눅 12:33 "Sell your possessions and give to those in need. This will store up treasure for you in heaven! And the purses of heaven never get old or develop holes. Your treasure will be safe; no thief can steal it and no moth can destroy it.
눅 12:34 Wherever your treasure is, there the desires of your heart will also be.
눅 12:35 "Be dressed for service and keep your lamps burning,
눅 12:36 as though you were waiting for your master to return from the wedding feast. Then you will be ready to open the door and let him in the moment he arrives and knocks.
눅 12:37 The servants who are ready and waiting for his return will be rewarded. I tell you the truth, he himself will seat them, put on an apron, and serve them as they sit and eat!
눅 12:38 He may come in the middle of the night or just before dawn①. But whenever he comes, he will reward the servants who are ready. / ①Greek in the second or third watch
눅 12:39 "Understand this： If a homeowner knew exactly when a burglar was coming, he would not permit his house to be broken into.
눅 12:40 You also must be ready all the time, for the Son of Man will come when least expected."
눅 12:41 Peter asked, "Lord, is that illustration just for us or for everyone?"
눅 12:42 And the Lord replied, "A faithful, sensible servant is one to whom the master can give the responsibility of managing his other household servants and feeding them.
눅 12:43 If the master returns and finds that the servant has done a good job, there will be a reward.
눅 12:44 I tell you the truth, the master will put that servant in charge of all he owns.
눅 12:45 But what if the servant thinks, `My master won't be back for a while,' and he begins beating the other servants, partying, and getting drunk?
눅 12:46 The master will return unannounced and unexpected, and he will cut the servant in pieces and banish him with the unfaithful.
눅 12:47 "And a servant who knows what the master wants, but isn't prepared and doesn't carry out those instructions, will be severely punished.
