눅 12:48 But someone who does not know, and then does something wrong, will be punished only lightly. When someone has been given much, much will be required in return; and when someone has been entrusted with much, even more will be required.
눅 12:49 "I have come to set the world on fire, and I wish it were already burning!
눅 12:50 I have a terrible baptism of suffering ahead of me, and I am under a heavy burden until it is accomplished.
눅 12:51 Do you think I have come to bring peace to the earth? No, I have come to divide people against each other!
눅 12:52 From now on families will be split apart, three in favor of me, and two against?or two in favor and three against.
눅 12:53 `Father will be divided against son and son against father; mother against daughter and daughter against mother; and mother-in-law against daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law.'①" / ①Mic 7.6
눅 12:54 Then Jesus turned to the crowd and said, "When you see clouds beginning to form in the west, you say, `Here comes a shower.' And you are right.
눅 12:55 When the south wind blows, you say, `Today will be a scorcher.' And it is.
눅 12:56 You fools! You know how to interpret the weather signs of the earth and sky, but you don't know how to interpret the present times.
눅 12:57 "Why can't you decide for yourselves what is right?
눅 12:58 When you are on the way to court with your accuser, try to settle the matter before you get there. Otherwise, your accuser may drag you before the judge, who will hand you over to an officer, who will throw you into prison.
눅 12:59 And if that happens, you won't be free again until you have paid the very last penny①." / ①Greek last lepton [the smallest Jewish coin]
눅 13:1 About this time Jesus was informed that Pilate had murdered some people from Galilee as they were offering sacrifices at the Temple.
눅 13:2 "Do you think those Galileans were worse sinners than all the other people from Galilee?" Jesus asked. "Is that why they suffered?
눅 13:3 Not at all! And you will perish, too, unless you repent of your sins and turn to God.
눅 13:4 And what about the eighteen people who died when the tower in Siloam fell on them? Were they the worst sinners in Jerusalem?
눅 13:5 No, and I tell you again that unless you repent, you will perish, too."
눅 13:6 Then Jesus told this story： "A man planted a fig tree in his garden and came again and again to see if there was any fruit on it, but he was always disappointed.
눅 13:7 Finally, he said to his gardener, `I've waited three years, and there hasn't been a single fig! Cut it down. It's just taking up space in the garden.'
눅 13:8 "The gardener answered, `Sir, give it one more chance. Leave it another year, and I'll give it special attention and plenty of fertilizer.
눅 13:9 If we get figs next year, fine. If not, then you can cut it down.'"
눅 13:10 One Sabbath day as Jesus was teaching in a synagogue,
눅 13:11 he saw a woman who had been crippled by an evil spirit. She had been bent double for eighteen years and was unable to stand up straight.
눅 13:12 When Jesus saw her, he called her over and said, "Dear woman, you are healed of your sickness!"
눅 13:13 Then he touched her, and instantly she could stand straight. How she praised God!
눅 13:14 But the leader in charge of the synagogue was indignant that Jesus had healed her on the Sabbath day. "There are six days of the week for working," he said to the crowd. "Come on those days to be healed, not on the Sabbath."
눅 13:15 But the Lord replied, "You hypocrites! Each of you works on the Sabbath day! Don't you untie your ox or your donkey from its stall on the Sabbath and lead it out for water?
눅 13:16 This dear woman, a daughter of Abraham, has been held in bondage by Satan for eighteen years. Isn't it right that she be released, even on the Sabbath?"
눅 13:17 This shamed his enemies, but all the people rejoiced at the wonderful things he did.
눅 13:18 Then Jesus said, "What is the Kingdom of God like? How can I illustrate it?
눅 13:19 It is like a tiny mustard seed that a man planted in a garden; it grows and becomes a tree, and the birds make nests in its branches."
눅 13:20 He also asked, "What else is the Kingdom of God like?
눅 13:21 It is like the yeast a woman used in making bread. Even though she put only a little yeast in three measures of flour, it permeated every part of the dough."
눅 13:22 Jesus went through the towns and villages, teaching as he went, always pressing on toward Jerusalem.
눅 13:23 Someone asked him, "Lord, will only a few be saved?" He replied,
눅 13:24 "Work hard to enter the narrow door to God's Kingdom, for many will try to enter but will fail.
눅 13:25 When the master of the house has locked the door, it will be too late. You will stand outside knocking and pleading, `Lord, open the door for us!' But he will reply, `I don't know you or where you come from.'
눅 13:26 Then you will say, `But we ate and drank with you, and you taught in our streets.'
눅 13:27 And he will reply, `I tell you, I don't know you or where you come from. Get away from me, all you who do evil.'
눅 13:28 "There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, for you will see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets in the Kingdom of God, but you will be thrown out.
눅 13:29 And people will come from all over the world?from east and west, north and south?to take their places in the Kingdom of God.
눅 13:30 And note this： Some who seem least important now will be the greatest then, and some who are the greatest now will be least important then①." / ①Greek Some are last who will be first, and some are first who will be last
눅 13:31 At that time some Pharisees said to him, "Get away from here if you want to live! Herod Antipas wants to kill you!"
눅 13:32 Jesus replied, "Go tell that fox that I will keep on casting out demons and healing people today and tomorrow; and the third day I will accomplish my purpose.
눅 13:33 Yes, today, tomorrow, and the next day I must proceed on my way. For it wouldn't do for a prophet of God to be killed except in Jerusalem!
눅 13:34 "O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones God's messengers! How often I have wanted to gather your children together as a hen protects her chicks beneath her wings, but you wouldn't let me.
눅 13:35 And now, look, your house is abandoned. And you will never see me again until you say, `Blessings on the one who comes in the name of the LORD!'①" / ①Ps 118.26
눅 14:1 One Sabbath day Jesus went to eat dinner in the home of a leader of the Pharisees, and the people were watching him closely.
눅 14:2 There was a man there whose arms and legs were swollen①. / ①Or who had dropsy
눅 14:3 Jesus asked the Pharisees and experts in religious law, "Is it permitted in the law to heal people on the Sabbath day, or not?"
눅 14:4 When they refused to answer, Jesus touched the sick man and healed him and sent him away.
눅 14:5 Then he turned to them and said, "Which of you doesn't work on the Sabbath? If your son① or your cow falls into a pit, don't you rush to get him out?" / ①Some manuscripts read donkey
눅 14:6 Again they could not answer.
눅 14:7 When Jesus noticed that all who had come to the dinner were trying to sit in the seats of honor near the head of the table, he gave them this advice.
눅 14:8 "When you are invited to a wedding feast, don't sit in the seat of honor. What if someone who is more distinguished than you has also been invited?
눅 14:9 The host will come and say, `Give this person your seat.' Then you will be embarrassed, and you will have to take whatever seat is left at the foot of the table!
눅 14:10 "Instead, take the lowest place at the foot of the table. Then when your host sees you, he will come and say, `Friend, we have a better place for you!' Then you will be honored in front of all the other guests.
눅 14:11 For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted."
눅 14:12 Then he turned to his host. "When you put on a luncheon or a banquet," he said, "don't invite your friends, brothers, relatives, and rich neighbors. For they will invite you back, and that will be your only reward.
눅 14:13 Instead, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.
눅 14:14 Then at the resurrection of the righteous, God will reward you for inviting those who could not repay you."
눅 14:15 Hearing this, a man sitting at the table with Jesus exclaimed, "What a blessing it will be to attend a banquet① in the Kingdom of God!" / ①Greek to eat bread
눅 14:16 Jesus replied with this story： "A man prepared a great feast and sent out many invitations.
눅 14:17 When the banquet was ready, he sent his servant to tell the guests, `Come, the banquet is ready.'
눅 14:18 But they all began making excuses. One said, `I have just bought a field and must inspect it. Please excuse me.'
눅 14:19 Another said, `I have just bought five pairs of oxen, and I want to try them out. Please excuse me.'
눅 14:20 Another said, `I now have a wife, so I can't come.'
눅 14:21 "The servant returned and told his master what they had said. His master was furious and said, `Go quickly into the streets and alleys of the town and invite the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame.'
눅 14:22 After the servant had done this, he reported, `There is still room for more.'
눅 14:23 So his master said, `Go out into the country lanes and behind the hedges and urge anyone you find to come, so that the house will be full.
눅 14:24 For none of those I first invited will get even the smallest taste of my banquet.'"
눅 14:25 A large crowd was following Jesus. He turned around and said to them,
눅 14:26 "If you want to be my disciple, you must hate everyone else by comparison?your father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters?yes, even your own life. Otherwise, you cannot be my disciple.
눅 14:27 And if you do not carry your own cross and follow me, you cannot be my disciple.
눅 14:28 "But don't begin until you count the cost. For who would begin construction of a building without first calculating the cost to see if there is enough money to finish it?
눅 14:29 Otherwise, you might complete only the foundation before running out of money, and then everyone would laugh at you.
눅 14:30 They would say, `There's the person who started that building and couldn't afford to finish it!'
눅 14:31 "Or what king would go to war against another king without first sitting down with his counselors to discuss whether his army of 10,000 could defeat the 20,000 soldiers marching against him?
눅 14:32 And if he can't, he will send a delegation to discuss terms of peace while the enemy is still far away.
눅 14:33 So you cannot become my disciple without giving up everything you own.
눅 14:34 "Salt is good for seasoning. But if it loses its flavor, how do you make it salty again?
눅 14:35 Flavorless salt is good neither for the soil nor for the manure pile. It is thrown away. Anyone with ears to hear should listen and understand!"
눅 15:1 Tax collectors and other notorious sinners often came to listen to Jesus teach.
눅 15:2 This made the Pharisees and teachers of religious law complain that he was associating with such sinful people?even eating with them!
눅 15:3 So Jesus told them this story.
눅 15:4 "If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them gets lost, what will he do? Won't he leave the ninety-nine others in the wilderness and go to search for the one that is lost until he finds it?
눅 15:5 And when he has found it, he will joyfully carry it home on his shoulders.
눅 15:6 When he arrives, he will call together his friends and neighbors, saying, `Rejoice with me because I have found my lost sheep.'
눅 15:7 In the same way, there is more joy in heaven over one lost sinner who repents and returns to God than over ninety-nine others who are righteous and haven't strayed away!
눅 15:8 "Or suppose a woman has ten silver coins① and loses one. Won't she light a lamp and sweep the entire house and search carefully until she finds it? / ①Greek ten drachmas. A drachma was the equivalent of a full day's wage
눅 15:9 And when she finds it, she will call in her friends and neighbors and say, `Rejoice with me because I have found my lost coin.'
눅 15:10 In the same way, there is joy in the presence of God's angels when even one sinner repents."
눅 15:11 To illustrate the point further, Jesus told them this story： "A man had two sons.
눅 15:12 The younger son told his father, `I want my share of your estate now before you die.' So his father agreed to divide his wealth between his sons.
눅 15:13 "A few days later this younger son packed all his belongings and moved to a distant land, and there he wasted all his money in wild living.
눅 15:14 About the time his money ran out, a great famine swept over the land, and he began to starve.
눅 15:15 He persuaded a local farmer to hire him, and the man sent him into his fields to feed the pigs.
눅 15:16 The young man became so hungry that even the pods he was feeding the pigs looked good to him. But no one gave him anything.
눅 15:17 "When he finally came to his senses, he said to himself, `At home even the hired servants have food enough to spare, and here I am dying of hunger!
눅 15:18 I will go home to my father and say, "Father, I have sinned against both heaven and you,
눅 15:19 and I am no longer worthy of being called your son. Please take me on as a hired servant."'
눅 15:20 "So he returned home to his father. And while he was still a long way off, his father saw him coming. Filled with love and compassion, he ran to his son, embraced him, and kissed him.
눅 15:21 His son said to him, `Father, I have sinned against both heaven and you, and I am no longer worthy of being called your son①.' / ①Some manuscripts add Please take me on as a hired servant
눅 15:22 "But his father said to the servants, `Quick! Bring the finest robe in the house and put it on him. Get a ring for his finger and sandals for his feet.
눅 15:23 And kill the calf we have been fattening. We must celebrate with a feast,
눅 15:24 for this son of mine was dead and has now returned to life. He was lost, but now he is found.' So the party began.
눅 15:25 "Meanwhile, the older son was in the fields working. When he returned home, he heard music and dancing in the house,
눅 15:26 and he asked one of the servants what was going on.
눅 15:27 `Your brother is back,' he was told, `and your father has killed the fattened calf. We are celebrating because of his safe return.'
눅 15:28 "The older brother was angry and wouldn't go in. His father came out and begged him,
눅 15:29 but he replied, `All these years I've slaved for you and never once refused to do a single thing you told me to. And in all that time you never gave me even one young goat for a feast with my friends.
눅 15:30 Yet when this son of yours comes back after squandering your money on prostitutes, you celebrate by killing the fattened calf!'
눅 15:31 "His father said to him, `Look, dear son, you have always stayed by me, and everything I have is yours.
눅 15:32 We had to celebrate this happy day. For your brother was dead and has come back to life! He was lost, but now he is found!'"
눅 16:1 Jesus told this story to his disciples： "There was a certain rich man who had a manager handling his affairs. One day a report came that the manager was wasting his employer's money.
눅 16:2 So the employer called him in and said, `What's this I hear about you? Get your report in order, because you are going to be fired.'
눅 16:3 "The manager thought to himself, `Now what? My boss has fired me. I don't have the strength to dig ditches, and I'm too proud to beg.
눅 16:4 Ah, I know how to ensure that I'll have plenty of friends who will give me a home when I am fired.'
눅 16:5 "So he invited each person who owed money to his employer to come and discuss the situation. He asked the first one, `How much do you owe him?'
눅 16:6 The man replied, `I owe him 800 gallons of olive oil.' So the manager told him, `Take the bill and quickly change it to 400 gallons①.' / ①Greek 100 baths . . . 50 [baths]
눅 16:7 "`And how much do you owe my employer?' he asked the next man. `I owe him 1,000 bushels of wheat,' was the reply. `Here,' the manager said, `take the bill and change it to 800 bushels①.' / ①Greek 100 korous . . . 80 [korous]
눅 16:8 "The rich man had to admire the dishonest rascal for being so shrewd. And it is true that the children of this world are more shrewd in dealing with the world around them than are the children of the light.
눅 16:9 Here's the lesson： Use your worldly resources to benefit others and make friends. Then, when your earthly possessions are gone, they will welcome you to an eternal home①. / ①Or you will be welcomed into eternal homes
눅 16:10 "If you are faithful in little things, you will be faithful in large ones. But if you are dishonest in little things, you won't be honest with greater responsibilities.
눅 16:11 And if you are untrustworthy about worldly wealth, who will trust you with the true riches of heaven?
눅 16:12 And if you are not faithful with other people's things, why should you be trusted with things of your own?
눅 16:13 "No one can serve two masters. For you will hate one and love the other; you will be devoted to one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money."
눅 16:14 The Pharisees, who dearly loved their money, heard all this and scoffed at him.
눅 16:15 Then he said to them, "You like to appear righteous in public, but God knows your hearts. What this world honors is detestable in the sight of God.
눅 16:16 "Until John the Baptist, the law of Moses and the messages of the prophets were your guides. But now the Good News of the Kingdom of God is preached, and everyone is eager to get in①. / ①Or everyone is urged to enter in
눅 16:17 But that doesn't mean that the law has lost its force. It is easier for heaven and earth to disappear than for the smallest point of God's law to be overturned.
눅 16:18 "For example, a man who divorces his wife and marries someone else commits adultery. And anyone who marries a woman divorced from her husband commits adultery."
눅 16:19 Jesus said, "There was a certain rich man who was splendidly clothed in purple and fine linen and who lived each day in luxury.
눅 16:20 At his gate lay a poor man named Lazarus who was covered with sores.
눅 16:21 As Lazarus lay there longing for scraps from the rich man's table, the dogs would come and lick his open sores.
눅 16:22 "Finally, the poor man died and was carried by the angels to be with Abraham①. The rich man also died and was buried, / ①Greek into Abraham's bosom
눅 16:23 and his soul went to the place of the dead①. There, in torment, he saw Abraham in the far distance with Lazarus at his side. / ①Greek to Hades
눅 16:24 "The rich man shouted, `Father Abraham, have some pity! Send Lazarus over here to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue. I am in anguish in these flames.'
눅 16:25 "But Abraham said to him, `Son, remember that during your lifetime you had everything you wanted, and Lazarus had nothing. So now he is here being comforted, and you are in anguish.
눅 16:26 And besides, there is a great chasm separating us. No one can cross over to you from here, and no one can cross over to us from there.'
눅 16:27 "Then the rich man said, `Please, Father Abraham, at least send him to my father's home.
눅 16:28 For I have five brothers, and I want him to warn them so they don't end up in this place of torment.'
눅 16:29 "But Abraham said, `Moses and the prophets have warned them. Your brothers can read what they wrote.'
눅 16:30 "The rich man replied, `No, Father Abraham! But if someone is sent to them from the dead, then they will repent of their sins and turn to God.'
눅 16:31 "But Abraham said, `If they won't listen to Moses and the prophets, they won't listen even if someone rises from the dead.'"
눅 17:1 One day Jesus said to his disciples, "There will always be temptations to sin, but what sorrow awaits the person who does the tempting!
눅 17:2 It would be better to be thrown into the sea with a millstone hung around your neck than to cause one of these little ones to fall into sin.
눅 17:3 So watch yourselves! "If another believer① sins, rebuke that person; then if there is repentance, forgive. / ①Greek If your brother
눅 17:4 Even if that person wrongs you seven times a day and each time turns again and asks forgiveness, you must forgive."
눅 17:5 The apostles said to the Lord, "Show us how to increase our faith."
눅 17:6 The Lord answered, "If you had faith even as small as a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, `May you be uprooted and thrown into the sea,' and it would obey you!
눅 17:7 "When a servant comes in from plowing or taking care of sheep, does his master say, `Come in and eat with me'?
눅 17:8 No, he says, `Prepare my meal, put on your apron, and serve me while I eat. Then you can eat later.'
눅 17:9 And does the master thank the servant for doing what he was told to do? Of course not.
눅 17:10 In the same way, when you obey me you should say, `We are unworthy servants who have simply done our duty.'"
눅 17:11 As Jesus continued on toward Jerusalem, he reached the border between Galilee and Samaria.
눅 17:12 As he entered a village there, ten lepers stood at a distance,
눅 17:13 crying out, "Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!"
눅 17:14 He looked at them and said, "Go show yourselves to the priests."① And as they went, they were cleansed of their leprosy. / ①See Lev 14.2-32
눅 17:15 One of them, when he saw that he was healed, came back to Jesus, shouting, "Praise God!"
눅 17:16 He fell to the ground at Jesus' feet, thanking him for what he had done. This man was a Samaritan.
눅 17:17 Jesus asked, "Didn't I heal ten men? Where are the other nine?
눅 17:18 Has no one returned to give glory to God except this foreigner?"
눅 17:19 And Jesus said to the man, "Stand up and go. Your faith has healed you①." / ①Or Your faith has saved you
눅 17:20 One day the Pharisees asked Jesus, "When will the Kingdom of God come?" Jesus replied, "The Kingdom of God can't be detected by visible signs①. / ①Or by your speculations
눅 17:21 You won't be able to say, `Here it is!' or `It's over there!' For the Kingdom of God is already among you①." / ①Or is within you, or is in your grasp
눅 17:22 Then he said to his disciples, "The time is coming when you will long to see the day when the Son of Man returns①, but you won't see it. / ①Or long for even one day with the Son of Man. "Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 17:23 People will tell you, `Look, there is the Son of Man,' or `Here he is,' but don't go out and follow them.
눅 17:24 For as the lightning flashes and lights up the sky from one end to the other, so it will be on the day when the Son of Man comes.
눅 17:25 But first the Son of Man must suffer terribly① and be rejected by this generation. / ①Or suffer many things
눅 17:26 "When the Son of Man returns, it will be like it was in Noah's day.
눅 17:27 In those days, the people enjoyed banquets and parties and weddings right up to the time Noah entered his boat and the flood came and destroyed them all.
눅 17:28 "And the world will be as it was in the days of Lot. People went about their daily business?eating and drinking, buying and selling, farming and building?
눅 17:29 until the morning Lot left Sodom. Then fire and burning sulfur rained down from heaven and destroyed them all.
눅 17:30 Yes, it will be `business as usual' right up to the day when the Son of Man is revealed.
눅 17:31 On that day a person out on the deck of a roof must not go down into the house to pack. A person out in the field must not return home.
눅 17:32 Remember what happened to Lot's wife!
눅 17:33 If you cling to your life, you will lose it, and if you let your life go, you will save it.
눅 17:34 That night two people will be asleep in one bed; one will be taken, the other left.
눅 17:35 Two women will be grinding flour together at the mill; one will be taken, the other left."
눅 17:36 ① / ①Some manuscripts add verse 36, Two men will be working in the field; one will be taken, the other left. Compare Matt 24.40
눅 17:37 "Where will this happen, Lord?"① the disciples asked. Jesus replied, "Just as the gathering of vultures shows there is a carcass nearby, so these signs indicate that the end is near."② / ①Greek "Where, Lord?" ②Greek "Wherever the carcass is, the vultures gather."
눅 18:1 One day Jesus told his disciples a story to show that they should always pray and never give up.
눅 18:2 "There was a judge in a certain city," he said, "who neither feared God nor cared about people.
눅 18:3 A widow of that city came to him repeatedly, saying, `Give me justice in this dispute with my enemy.'
눅 18:4 The judge ignored her for a while, but finally he said to himself, `I don't fear God or care about people,
눅 18:5 but this woman is driving me crazy. I'm going to see that she gets justice, because she is wearing me out with her constant requests!'"
눅 18:6 Then the Lord said, "Learn a lesson from this unjust judge.
눅 18:7 Even he rendered a just decision in the end. So don't you think God will surely give justice to his chosen people who cry out to him day and night? Will he keep putting them off?
눅 18:8 I tell you, he will grant justice to them quickly! But when the Son of Man① returns, how many will he find on the earth who have faith?" / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 18:9 Then Jesus told this story to some who had great confidence in their own righteousness and scorned everyone else.
눅 18:10 "Two men went to the Temple to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a despised tax collector.
눅 18:11 The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed this prayer①： `I thank you, God, that I am not a sinner like everyone else. For I don't cheat, I don't sin, and I don't commit adultery. I'm certainly not like that tax collector! / ①Some manuscripts read stood and prayed this prayer to himself
눅 18:12 I fast twice a week, and I give you a tenth of my income.'
눅 18:13 "But the tax collector stood at a distance and dared not even lift his eyes to heaven as he prayed. Instead, he beat his chest in sorrow, saying, `O God, be merciful to me, for I am a sinner.'
눅 18:14 I tell you, this sinner, not the Pharisee, returned home justified before God. For those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted."
눅 18:15 One day some parents brought their little children to Jesus so he could touch and bless them. But when the disciples saw this, they scolded the parents for bothering him.
눅 18:16 Then Jesus called for the children and said to the disciples, "Let the children come to me. Don't stop them! For the Kingdom of God belongs to those who are like these children.
눅 18:17 I tell you the truth, anyone who doesn't receive the Kingdom of God like a child will never enter it."
눅 18:18 Once a religious leader asked Jesus this question： "Good Teacher, what should I do to inherit eternal life?"
눅 18:19 "Why do you call me good?" Jesus asked him. "Only God is truly good.
눅 18:20 But to answer your question, you know the commandments： `You must not commit adultery. You must not murder. You must not steal. You must not testify falsely. Honor your father and mother.'①" / ①Exod 20.12-16; Deut 5.16-20
눅 18:21 The man replied, "I've obeyed all these commandments since I was young."
눅 18:22 When Jesus heard his answer, he said, "There is still one thing you haven't done. Sell all your possessions and give the money to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me."
눅 18:23 But when the man heard this he became very sad, for he was very rich.
눅 18:24 When Jesus saw this①, he said, "How hard it is for the rich to enter the Kingdom of God! / ①Some manuscripts read When Jesus saw how sad the man was
눅 18:25 In fact, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the Kingdom of God!"
눅 18:26 Those who heard this said, "Then who in the world can be saved?"
눅 18:27 He replied, "What is impossible for people is possible with God."
눅 18:28 Peter said, "We've left our homes to follow you."
눅 18:29 "Yes," Jesus replied, "and I assure you that everyone who has given up house or wife or brothers or parents or children, for the sake of the Kingdom of God,
눅 18:30 will be repaid many times over in this life, and will have eternal life in the world to come."
눅 18:31 Taking the twelve disciples aside, Jesus said, "Listen, we're going up to Jerusalem, where all the predictions of the prophets concerning the Son of Man will come true.
눅 18:32 He will be handed over to the Romans①, and he will be mocked, treated shamefully, and spit upon. / ①Greek the Gentiles
눅 18:33 They will flog him with a whip and kill him, but on the third day he will rise again."
눅 18:34 But they didn't understand any of this. The significance of his words was hidden from them, and they failed to grasp what he was talking about.
눅 18:35 As Jesus approached Jericho, a blind beggar was sitting beside the road.
눅 18:36 When he heard the noise of a crowd going past, he asked what was happening.
눅 18:37 They told him that Jesus the Nazarene① was going by. / ①Or Jesus of Nazareth
눅 18:38 So he began shouting, "Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!"
눅 18:39 "Be quiet!" the people in front yelled at him. But he only shouted louder, "Son of David, have mercy on me!"
눅 18:40 When Jesus heard him, he stopped and ordered that the man be brought to him. As the man came near, Jesus asked him,
눅 18:41 "What do you want me to do for you?" "Lord," he said, "I want to see!"
눅 18:42 And Jesus said, "All right, receive your sight! Your faith has healed you."
눅 18:43 Instantly the man could see, and he followed Jesus, praising God. And all who saw it praised God, too.
눅 19:1 Jesus entered Jericho and made his way through the town.
눅 19:2 There was a man there named Zacchaeus. He was the chief tax collector in the region, and he had become very rich.
눅 19:3 He tried to get a look at Jesus, but he was too short to see over the crowd.
눅 19:4 So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore-fig tree beside the road, for Jesus was going to pass that way.
눅 19:5 When Jesus came by, he looked up at Zacchaeus and called him by name. "Zacchaeus!" he said. "Quick, come down! I must be a guest in your home today."
눅 19:6 Zacchaeus quickly climbed down and took Jesus to his house in great excitement and joy.
눅 19:7 But the people were displeased. "He has gone to be the guest of a notorious sinner," they grumbled.
눅 19:8 Meanwhile, Zacchaeus stood before the Lord and said, "I will give half my wealth to the poor, Lord, and if I have cheated people on their taxes, I will give them back four times as much!"
눅 19:9 Jesus responded, "Salvation has come to this home today, for this man has shown himself to be a true son of Abraham.
눅 19:10 For the Son of Man① came to seek and save those who are lost." / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 19:11 The crowd was listening to everything Jesus said. And because he was nearing Jerusalem, he told them a story to correct the impression that the Kingdom of God would begin right away.
눅 19:12 He said, "A nobleman was called away to a distant empire to be crowned king and then return.
눅 19:13 Before he left, he called together ten of his servants and divided among them ten pounds of silver①, saying, `Invest this for me while I am gone.' / ①Greek ten minas; one mina was worth about three months' wages
눅 19:14 But his people hated him and sent a delegation after him to say, `We do not want him to be our king.'
눅 19:15 "After he was crowned king, he returned and called in the servants to whom he had given the money. He wanted to find out what their profits were.
눅 19:16 The first servant reported, `Master, I invested your money and made ten times the original amount!'
눅 19:17 "`Well done!' the king exclaimed. `You are a good servant. You have been faithful with the little I entrusted to you, so you will be governor of ten cities as your reward.'
눅 19:18 "The next servant reported, `Master, I invested your money and made five times the original amount.'
눅 19:19 "`Well done!' the king said. `You will be governor over five cities.'
눅 19:20 "But the third servant brought back only the original amount of money and said, `Master, I hid your money and kept it safe.
눅 19:21 I was afraid because you are a hard man to deal with, taking what isn't yours and harvesting crops you didn't plant.'
눅 19:22 "`You wicked servant!' the king roared. `Your own words condemn you. If you knew that I'm a hard man who takes what isn't mine and harvests crops I didn't plant,
눅 19:23 why didn't you deposit my money in the bank? At least I could have gotten some interest on it.'
눅 19:24 "Then, turning to the others standing nearby, the king ordered, `Take the money from this servant, and give it to the one who has ten pounds.'
눅 19:25 "`But, master,' they said, `he already has ten pounds!'
눅 19:26 "`Yes,' the king replied, `and to those who use well what they are given, even more will be given. But from those who do nothing, even what little they have will be taken away.
눅 19:27 And as for these enemies of mine who didn't want me to be their king?bring them in and execute them right here in front of me.'"
눅 19:28 After telling this story, Jesus went on toward Jerusalem, walking ahead of his disciples.
눅 19:29 As he came to the towns of Bethphage and Bethany on the Mount of Olives, he sent two disciples ahead.
눅 19:30 "Go into that village over there," he told them. "As you enter it, you will see a young donkey tied there that no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.
눅 19:31 If anyone asks, `Why are you untying that colt?' just say, `The Lord needs it.'"
눅 19:32 So they went and found the colt, just as Jesus had said.
눅 19:33 And sure enough, as they were untying it, the owners asked them, "Why are you untying that colt?"
눅 19:34 And the disciples simply replied, "The Lord needs it."
눅 19:35 So they brought the colt to Jesus and threw their garments over it for him to ride on.
눅 19:36 As he rode along, the crowds spread out their garments on the road ahead of him.
눅 19:37 When he reached the place where the road started down the Mount of Olives, all of his followers began to shout and sing as they walked along, praising God for all the wonderful miracles they had seen.
눅 19:38 "Blessings on the King who comes in the name of the LORD! Peace in heaven, and glory in highest heaven!"① / ①Pss 118.26; 148.1
눅 19:39 But some of the Pharisees among the crowd said, "Teacher, rebuke your followers for saying things like that!"
눅 19:40 He replied, "If they kept quiet, the stones along the road would burst into cheers!"
눅 19:41 But as he came closer to Jerusalem and saw the city ahead, he began to weep.
눅 19:42 "How I wish today that you of all people would understand the way to peace. But now it is too late, and peace is hidden from your eyes.
눅 19:43 Before long your enemies will build ramparts against your walls and encircle you and close in on you from every side.
눅 19:44 They will crush you into the ground, and your children with you. Your enemies will not leave a single stone in place, because you did not accept your opportunity for salvation."
눅 19:45 Then Jesus entered the Temple and began to drive out the people selling animals for sacrifices.
눅 19:46 He said to them, "The Scriptures declare, `My Temple will be a house of prayer,' but you have turned it into a den of thieves."① / ①Isa 56.7; Jer 7.11
눅 19:47 After that, he taught daily in the Temple, but the leading priests, the teachers of religious law, and the other leaders of the people began planning how to kill him.
눅 19:48 But they could think of nothing, because all the people hung on every word he said.
눅 20:1 One day as Jesus was teaching the people and preaching the Good News in the Temple, the leading priests, the teachers of religious law, and the elders came up to him.
눅 20:2 They demanded, "By what authority are you doing all these things? Who gave you the right?"
눅 20:3 "Let me ask you a question first," he replied.
눅 20:4 "Did John's authority to baptize come from heaven, or was it merely human?"
눅 20:5 They talked it over among themselves. "If we say it was from heaven, he will ask why we didn't believe John.
눅 20:6 But if we say it was merely human, the people will stone us because they are convinced John was a prophet."
눅 20:7 So they finally replied that they didn't know.
눅 20:8 And Jesus responded, "Then I won't tell you by what authority I do these things."
눅 20:9 Now Jesus turned to the people again and told them this story： "A man planted a vineyard, leased it to tenant farmers, and moved to another country to live for several years.
눅 20:10 At the time of the grape harvest, he sent one of his servants to collect his share of the crop. But the farmers attacked the servant, beat him up, and sent him back empty-handed.
눅 20:11 So the owner sent another servant, but they also insulted him, beat him up, and sent him away empty-handed.
눅 20:12 A third man was sent, and they wounded him and chased him away.
눅 20:13 "`What will I do?' the owner asked himself. `I know! I'll send my cherished son. Surely they will respect him.'
눅 20:14 "But when the tenant farmers saw his son, they said to each other, `Here comes the heir to this estate. Let's kill him and get the estate for ourselves!'
눅 20:15 So they dragged him out of the vineyard and murdered him. "What do you suppose the owner of the vineyard will do to them?" Jesus asked.
눅 20:16 "I'll tell you?he will come and kill those farmers and lease the vineyard to others." "How terrible that such a thing should ever happen," his listeners protested.
눅 20:17 Jesus looked at them and said, "Then what does this Scripture mean? `The stone that the builders rejected has now become the cornerstone.'① / ①Ps 118.22
눅 20:18 Everyone who stumbles over that stone will be broken to pieces, and it will crush anyone it falls on."
눅 20:19 The teachers of religious law and the leading priests wanted to arrest Jesus immediately because they realized he was telling the story against them?they were the wicked farmers. But they were afraid of the people's reaction.
눅 20:20 Watching for their opportunity, the leaders sent spies pretending to be honest men. They tried to get Jesus to say something that could be reported to the Roman governor so he would arrest Jesus.
눅 20:21 "Teacher," they said, "we know that you speak and teach what is right and are not influenced by what others think. You teach the way of God truthfully.
눅 20:22 Now tell us?is it right for us to pay taxes to Caesar or not?"
눅 20:23 He saw through their trickery and said,
눅 20:24 "Show me a Roman coin①. Whose picture and title are stamped on it?" "Caesar's," they replied. / ①Greek a denarius
눅 20:25 "Well then," he said, "give to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and give to God what belongs to God."
눅 20:26 So they failed to trap him by what he said in front of the people. Instead, they were amazed by his answer, and they became silent.
눅 20:27 Then Jesus was approached by some Sadducees?religious leaders who say there is no resurrection from the dead.
눅 20:28 They posed this question： "Teacher, Moses gave us a law that if a man dies, leaving a wife but no children, his brother should marry the widow and have a child who will carry on the brother's name①. / ①See Deut 25.5-6
눅 20:29 Well, suppose there were seven brothers. The oldest one married and then died without children.
눅 20:30 So the second brother married the widow, but he also died.
눅 20:31 Then the third brother married her. This continued with all seven of them, who died without children.
눅 20:32 Finally, the woman also died.
눅 20:33 So tell us, whose wife will she be in the resurrection? For all seven were married to her!"
눅 20:34 Jesus replied, "Marriage is for people here on earth.
눅 20:35 But in the age to come, those worthy of being raised from the dead will neither marry nor be given in marriage.
눅 20:36 And they will never die again. In this respect they will be like angels. They are children of God and children of the resurrection.
눅 20:37 "But now, as to whether the dead will be raised?even Moses proved this when he wrote about the burning bush. Long after Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob had died, he referred to the Lord① as `the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.'② / ①Greek when he wrote about the bush. He referred to the Lord ②Exod 3.6
눅 20:38 So he is the God of the living, not the dead, for they are all alive to him."
눅 20:39 "Well said, Teacher!" remarked some of the teachers of religious law who were standing there.
눅 20:40 And then no one dared to ask him any more questions.
눅 20:41 Then Jesus presented them with a question. "Why is it," he asked, "that the Messiah is said to be the son of David?
눅 20:42 For David himself wrote in the book of Psalms： `The LORD said to my Lord, Sit in the place of honor at my right hand
눅 20:43 until I humble your enemies, making them a footstool under your feet.'① / ①Ps 110.1
눅 20:44 Since David called the Messiah `Lord,' how can the Messiah be his son?"
눅 20:45 Then, with the crowds listening, he turned to his disciples and said,
눅 20:46 "Beware of these teachers of religious law! For they like to parade around in flowing robes and love to receive respectful greetings as they walk in the marketplaces. And how they love the seats of honor in the synagogues and the head table at banquets.
눅 20:47 Yet they shamelessly cheat widows out of their property and then pretend to be pious by making long prayers in public. Because of this, they will be severely punished."
눅 21:1 While Jesus was in the Temple, he watched the rich people dropping their gifts in the collection box.
눅 21:2 Then a poor widow came by and dropped in two small coins①. / ①Greek two lepta [the smallest of Jewish coins]
눅 21:3 "I tell you the truth," Jesus said, "this poor widow has given more than all the rest of them.
눅 21:4 For they have given a tiny part of their surplus, but she, poor as she is, has given everything she has."
눅 21:5 Some of his disciples began talking about the majestic stonework of the Temple and the memorial decorations on the walls. But Jesus said,
눅 21:6 "The time is coming when all these things will be completely demolished. Not one stone will be left on top of another!"
눅 21:7 "Teacher," they asked, "when will all this happen? What sign will show us that these things are about to take place?"
눅 21:8 He replied, "Don't let anyone mislead you, for many will come in my name, claiming, `I am the Messiah,'① and saying, `The time has come!' But don't believe them. / ①Greek claiming, `I am.'
눅 21:9 And when you hear of wars and insurrections, don't panic. Yes, these things must take place first, but the end won't follow immediately."
눅 21:10 Then he added, "Nation will go to war against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
눅 21:11 There will be great earthquakes, and there will be famines and plagues in many lands, and there will be terrifying things and great miraculous signs from heaven.
눅 21:12 "But before all this occurs, there will be a time of great persecution. You will be dragged into synagogues and prisons, and you will stand trial before kings and governors because you are my followers.
눅 21:13 But this will be your opportunity to tell them about me①. / ①Or This will be your testimony against them
눅 21:14 So don't worry in advance about how to answer the charges against you,
눅 21:15 for I will give you the right words and such wisdom that none of your opponents will be able to reply or refute you!
눅 21:16 Even those closest to you?your parents, brothers, relatives, and friends?will betray you. They will even kill some of you.
눅 21:17 And everyone will hate you because you are my followers①. / ①Greek on account of my name
눅 21:18 But not a hair of your head will perish!
눅 21:19 By standing firm, you will win your souls.
눅 21:20 "And when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then you will know that the time of its destruction has arrived.
눅 21:21 Then those in Judea must flee to the hills. Those in Jerusalem must get out, and those out in the country should not return to the city.
눅 21:22 For those will be days of God's vengeance, and the prophetic words of the Scriptures will be fulfilled.
눅 21:23 How terrible it will be for pregnant women and for nursing mothers in those days. For there will be disaster in the land and great anger against this people.
눅 21:24 They will be killed by the sword or sent away as captives to all the nations of the world. And Jerusalem will be trampled down by the Gentiles until the period of the Gentiles comes to an end.
눅 21:25 "And there will be strange signs in the sun, moon, and stars. And here on earth the nations will be in turmoil, perplexed by the roaring seas and strange tides.
눅 21:26 People will be terrified at what they see coming upon the earth, for the powers in the heavens will be shaken.
눅 21:27 Then everyone will see the Son of Man① coming on a cloud with power and great glory②. / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself ②See Dan 7.13
눅 21:28 So when all these things begin to happen, stand and look up, for your salvation is near!"
눅 21:29 Then he gave them this illustration： "Notice the fig tree, or any other tree.
눅 21:30 When the leaves come out, you know without being told that summer is near.
눅 21:31 In the same way, when you see all these things taking place, you can know that the Kingdom of God is near.
눅 21:32 I tell you the truth, this generation will not pass from the scene until all these things have taken place.
눅 21:33 Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words will never disappear.
눅 21:34 "Watch out! Don't let your hearts be dulled by carousing and drunkenness, and by the worries of this life. Don't let that day catch you unaware,
눅 21:35 like a trap. For that day will come upon everyone living on the earth.
눅 21:36 Keep alert at all times. And pray that you might be strong enough to escape these coming horrors and stand before the Son of Man."
눅 21:37 Every day Jesus went to the Temple to teach, and each evening he returned to spend the night on the Mount of Olives.
눅 21:38 The crowds gathered at the Temple early each morning to hear him.
눅 22:1 The Festival of Unleavened Bread, which is also called Passover, was approaching.
눅 22:2 The leading priests and teachers of religious law were plotting how to kill Jesus, but they were afraid of the people's reaction.
눅 22:3 Then Satan entered into Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve disciples,
눅 22:4 and he went to the leading priests and captains of the Temple guard to discuss the best way to betray Jesus to them.
눅 22:5 They were delighted, and they promised to give him money.
눅 22:6 So he agreed and began looking for an opportunity to betray Jesus so they could arrest him when the crowds weren't around.
눅 22:7 Now the Festival of Unleavened Bread arrived, when the Passover lamb is sacrificed.
눅 22:8 Jesus sent Peter and John ahead and said, "Go and prepare the Passover meal, so we can eat it together."
눅 22:9 "Where do you want us to prepare it?" they asked him.
눅 22:10 He replied, "As soon as you enter Jerusalem, a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you. Follow him. At the house he enters,
눅 22:11 say to the owner, `The Teacher asks： Where is the guest room where I can eat the Passover meal with my disciples?'
눅 22:12 He will take you upstairs to a large room that is already set up. That is where you should prepare our meal."
눅 22:13 They went off to the city and found everything just as Jesus had said, and they prepared the Passover meal there.
눅 22:14 When the time came, Jesus and the apostles sat down together at the table①. / ①Or reclined together
눅 22:15 Jesus said, "I have been very eager to eat this Passover meal with you before my suffering begins.
눅 22:16 For I tell you now that I won't eat this meal again until its meaning is fulfilled in the Kingdom of God."
눅 22:17 Then he took a cup of wine and gave thanks to God for it. Then he said, "Take this and share it among yourselves.
눅 22:18 For I will not drink wine again until the Kingdom of God has come."
눅 22:19 He took some bread and gave thanks to God for it. Then he broke it in pieces and gave it to the disciples, saying, "This is my body, which is given for you. Do this to remember me."
눅 22:20 After supper he took another cup of wine and said, "This cup is the new covenant between God and his people?an agreement confirmed with my blood, which is poured out as a sacrifice for you①. / ①Some manuscripts omit 22.19b-20, which is given for you . . . which is poured out as a sacrifice for you
눅 22:21 "But here at this table, sitting among us as a friend, is the man who will betray me.
눅 22:22 For it has been determined that the Son of Man① must die. But what sorrow awaits the one who betrays him." / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 22:23 The disciples began to ask each other which of them would ever do such a thing.
눅 22:24 Then they began to argue among themselves about who would be the greatest among them.
눅 22:25 Jesus told them, "In this world the kings and great men lord it over their people, yet they are called `friends of the people.'
눅 22:26 But among you it will be different. Those who are the greatest among you should take the lowest rank, and the leader should be like a servant.
눅 22:27 Who is more important, the one who sits at the table or the one who serves? The one who sits at the table, of course. But not here! For I am among you as one who serves.
눅 22:28 "You have stayed with me in my time of trial.
눅 22:29 And just as my Father has granted me a Kingdom, I now grant you the right
눅 22:30 to eat and drink at my table in my Kingdom. And you will sit on thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
눅 22:31 "Simon, Simon, Satan has asked to sift each of you like wheat.
눅 22:32 But I have pleaded in prayer for you, Simon, that your faith should not fail. So when you have repented and turned to me again, strengthen your brothers."
눅 22:33 Peter said, "Lord, I am ready to go to prison with you, and even to die with you."
눅 22:34 But Jesus said, "Peter, let me tell you something. Before the rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will deny three times that you even know me."
눅 22:35 Then Jesus asked them, "When I sent you out to preach the Good News and you did not have money, a traveler's bag, or extra clothing, did you need anything?" "No," they replied.
눅 22:36 "But now," he said, "take your money and a traveler's bag. And if you don't have a sword, sell your cloak and buy one!
눅 22:37 For the time has come for this prophecy about me to be fulfilled： `He was counted among the rebels.'① Yes, everything written about me by the prophets will come true." / ①Isa 53.12
눅 22:38 "Look, Lord," they replied, "we have two swords among us." "That's enough," he said.
눅 22:39 Then, accompanied by the disciples, Jesus left the upstairs room and went as usual to the Mount of Olives.
눅 22:40 There he told them, "Pray that you will not give in to temptation."
눅 22:41 He walked away, about a stone's throw, and knelt down and prayed,
눅 22:42 "Father, if you are willing, please take this cup of suffering away from me. Yet I want your will to be done, not mine."
눅 22:43 Then an angel from heaven appeared and strengthened him.
눅 22:44 He prayed more fervently, and he was in such agony of spirit that his sweat fell to the ground like great drops of blood①. / ①Verses 43 and 44 are not included in many ancient manuscripts
눅 22:45 At last he stood up again and returned to the disciples, only to find them asleep, exhausted from grief.
눅 22:46 "Why are you sleeping?" he asked them. "Get up and pray, so that you will not give in to temptation."
눅 22:47 But even as Jesus said this, a crowd approached, led by Judas, one of the twelve disciples. Judas walked over to Jesus to greet him with a kiss.
눅 22:48 But Jesus said, "Judas, would you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?"
눅 22:49 When the other disciples saw what was about to happen, they exclaimed, "Lord, should we fight? We brought the swords!"
눅 22:50 And one of them struck at the high priest's slave, slashing off his right ear.
눅 22:51 But Jesus said, "No more of this." And he touched the man's ear and healed him.
눅 22:52 Then Jesus spoke to the leading priests, the captains of the Temple guard, and the elders who had come for him. "Am I some dangerous revolutionary," he asked, "that you come with swords and clubs to arrest me?
눅 22:53 Why didn't you arrest me in the Temple? I was there every day. But this is your moment, the time when the power of darkness reigns."
눅 22:54 So they arrested him and led him to the high priest's home. And Peter followed at a distance.
눅 22:55 The guards lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat around it, and Peter joined them there.
눅 22:56 A servant girl noticed him in the firelight and began staring at him. Finally she said, "This man was one of Jesus' followers!"
눅 22:57 But Peter denied it. "Woman," he said, "I don't even know him!"
눅 22:58 After a while someone else looked at him and said, "You must be one of them!" "No, man, I'm not!" Peter retorted.
눅 22:59 About an hour later someone else insisted, "This must be one of them, because he is a Galilean, too."
눅 22:60 But Peter said, "Man, I don't know what you are talking about." And immediately, while he was still speaking, the rooster crowed.
눅 22:61 At that moment the Lord turned and looked at Peter. Suddenly, the Lord's words flashed through Peter's mind： "Before the rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will deny three times that you even know me."
눅 22:62 And Peter left the courtyard, weeping bitterly.
눅 22:63 The guards in charge of Jesus began mocking and beating him.
눅 22:64 They blindfolded him and said, "Prophesy to us! Who hit you that time?"
눅 22:65 And they hurled all sorts of terrible insults at him.
눅 22:66 At daybreak all the elders of the people assembled, including the leading priests and the teachers of religious law. Jesus was led before this high council①, / ①Greek before their Sanhedrin
눅 22:67 and they said, "Tell us, are you the Messiah?" But he replied, "If I tell you, you won't believe me.
눅 22:68 And if I ask you a question, you won't answer.
눅 22:69 But from now on the Son of Man will be seated in the place of power at God's right hand①." / ①See Ps 110.1
눅 22:70 They all shouted, "So, are you claiming to be the Son of God?" And he replied, "You say that I am."
눅 22:71 "Why do we need other witnesses?" they said. "We ourselves heard him say it."
눅 23:1 Then the entire council took Jesus to Pilate, the Roman governor.
눅 23:2 They began to state their case： "This man has been leading our people astray by telling them not to pay their taxes to the Roman government and by claiming he is the Messiah, a king."
눅 23:3 So Pilate asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" Jesus replied, "You have said it."
눅 23:4 Pilate turned to the leading priests and to the crowd and said, "I find nothing wrong with this man!"
눅 23:5 Then they became insistent. "But he is causing riots by his teaching wherever he goes?all over Judea, from Galilee to Jerusalem!"
눅 23:6 "Oh, is he a Galilean?" Pilate asked.
눅 23:7 When they said that he was, Pilate sent him to Herod Antipas, because Galilee was under Herod's jurisdiction, and Herod happened to be in Jerusalem at the time.
눅 23:8 Herod was delighted at the opportunity to see Jesus, because he had heard about him and had been hoping for a long time to see him perform a miracle.
눅 23:9 He asked Jesus question after question, but Jesus refused to answer.
눅 23:10 Meanwhile, the leading priests and the teachers of religious law stood there shouting their accusations.
눅 23:11 Then Herod and his soldiers began mocking and ridiculing Jesus. Finally, they put a royal robe on him and sent him back to Pilate.
눅 23:12 (Herod and Pilate, who had been enemies before, became friends that day)
눅 23:13 Then Pilate called together the leading priests and other religious leaders, along with the people,
눅 23:14 and he announced his verdict. "You brought this man to me, accusing him of leading a revolt. I have examined him thoroughly on this point in your presence and find him innocent.
눅 23:15 Herod came to the same conclusion and sent him back to us. Nothing this man has done calls for the death penalty.
눅 23:16 So I will have him flogged, and then I will release him."
눅 23:17 ① / ①Some manuscripts add verse 17, Now it was necessary for him to release one prisoner to them during the Passover celebration. Compare Matt 27.15; Mark 15.6; John 18.39
눅 23:18 Then a mighty roar rose from the crowd, and with one voice they shouted, "Kill him, and release Barabbas to us!"
눅 23:19 (Barabbas was in prison for taking part in an insurrection in Jerusalem against the government, and for murder.)
눅 23:20 Pilate argued with them, because he wanted to release Jesus.
눅 23:21 But they kept shouting, "Crucify him! Crucify him!"
눅 23:22 For the third time he demanded, "Why? What crime has he committed? I have found no reason to sentence him to death. So I will have him flogged, and then I will release him."
눅 23:23 But the mob shouted louder and louder, demanding that Jesus be crucified, and their voices prevailed.
눅 23:24 So Pilate sentenced Jesus to die as they demanded.
눅 23:25 As they had requested, he released Barabbas, the man in prison for insurrection and murder. But he turned Jesus over to them to do as they wished.
눅 23:26 As they led Jesus away, a man named Simon, who was from Cyrene①, happened to be coming in from the countryside. The soldiers seized him and put the cross on him and made him carry it behind Jesus. / ①Cyrene was a city in northern Africa
눅 23:27 A large crowd trailed behind, including many grief-stricken women.
눅 23:28 But Jesus turned and said to them, "Daughters of Jerusalem, don't weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
눅 23:29 For the days are coming when they will say, `Fortunate indeed are the women who are childless, the wombs that have not borne a child and the breasts that have never nursed.'
눅 23:30 People will beg the mountains, `Fall on us,' and plead with the hills, `Bury us.'① / ①Hos 10.8
눅 23:31 For if these things are done when the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?①" / ①Or If these things are done to me, the living tree, what will happen to you, the dry tree?
눅 23:32 Two others, both criminals, were led out to be executed with him.
눅 23:33 When they came to a place called The Skull①, they nailed him to the cross. And the criminals were also crucified?one on his right and one on his left. / ①Sometimes rendered Calvary, which comes from the Latin word for "skull."
눅 23:34 Jesus said, "Father, forgive them, for they don't know what they are doing."① And the soldiers gambled for his clothes by throwing dice②. / ①This sentence is not included in many ancient manuscripts ②Greek by casting lots. See Ps 22.18
눅 23:35 The crowd watched and the leaders scoffed. "He saved others," they said, "let him save himself if he is really God's Messiah, the Chosen One."
눅 23:36 The soldiers mocked him, too, by offering him a drink of sour wine.
눅 23:37 They called out to him, "If you are the King of the Jews, save yourself!"
눅 23:38 A sign was fastened to the cross above him with these words： "This is the King of the Jews."
눅 23:39 One of the criminals hanging beside him scoffed, "So you're the Messiah, are you? Prove it by saving yourself?and us, too, while you're at it!"
눅 23:40 But the other criminal protested, "Don't you fear God even when you have been sentenced to die?
눅 23:41 We deserve to die for our crimes, but this man hasn't done anything wrong."
눅 23:42 Then he said, "Jesus, remember me when you come into your Kingdom."
눅 23:43 And Jesus replied, "I assure you, today you will be with me in paradise."
눅 23:44 By this time it was noon, and darkness fell across the whole land until three o'clock.
눅 23:45 The light from the sun was gone. And suddenly, the curtain in the sanctuary of the Temple was torn down the middle.
눅 23:46 Then Jesus shouted, "Father, I entrust my spirit into your hands!"① And with those words he breathed his last. / ①Ps 31.5
눅 23:47 When the Roman officer① overseeing the execution saw what had happened, he worshiped God and said, "Surely this man was innocent②." / ①Greek the centurion ②Or righteous
눅 23:48 And when all the crowd that came to see the crucifixion saw what had happened, they went home in deep sorrow①. / ①Greek went home beating their breasts
눅 23:49 But Jesus' friends, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, stood at a distance watching.
눅 23:50 Now there was a good and righteous man named Joseph. He was a member of the Jewish high council,
눅 23:51 but he had not agreed with the decision and actions of the other religious leaders. He was from the town of Arimathea in Judea, and he was waiting for the Kingdom of God to come.
눅 23:52 He went to Pilate and asked for Jesus' body.
눅 23:53 Then he took the body down from the cross and wrapped it in a long sheet of linen cloth and laid it in a new tomb that had been carved out of rock.
눅 23:54 This was done late on Friday afternoon, the day of preparation①, as the Sabbath was about to begin. / ①Greek It was the day of preparation
눅 23:55 As his body was taken away, the women from Galilee followed and saw the tomb where his body was placed.
눅 23:56 Then they went home and prepared spices and ointments to anoint his body. But by the time they were finished the Sabbath had begun, so they rested as required by the law.
눅 24:1 But very early on Sunday morning① the women went to the tomb, taking the spices they had prepared. / ①Greek But on the first day of the week, very early in the morning
눅 24:2 They found that the stone had been rolled away from the entrance.
눅 24:3 So they went in, but they didn't find the body of the Lord Jesus.
눅 24:4 As they stood there puzzled, two men suddenly appeared to them, clothed in dazzling robes.
눅 24:5 The women were terrified and bowed with their faces to the ground. Then the men asked, "Why are you looking among the dead for someone who is alive?
눅 24:6 He isn't here! He is risen from the dead! Remember what he told you back in Galilee,
눅 24:7 that the Son of Man① must be betrayed into the hands of sinful men and be crucified, and that he would rise again on the third day." / ①"Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
눅 24:8 Then they remembered that he had said this.
눅 24:9 So they rushed back from the tomb to tell his eleven disciples?and everyone else?what had happened.
눅 24:10 It was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and several other women who told the apostles what had happened.
눅 24:11 But the story sounded like nonsense to the men, so they didn't believe it.
눅 24:12 However, Peter jumped up and ran to the tomb to look. Stooping, he peered in and saw the empty linen wrappings; then he went home again, wondering what had happened.
눅 24:13 That same day two of Jesus' followers were walking to the village of Emmaus, seven miles① from Jerusalem. / ①Greek 60 stadia [11.1 kilometers]
눅 24:14 As they walked along they were talking about everything that had happened.
눅 24:15 As they talked and discussed these things, Jesus himself suddenly came and began walking with them.
눅 24:16 But God kept them from recognizing him.
눅 24:17 He asked them, "What are you discussing so intently as you walk along?" They stopped short, sadness written across their faces.
눅 24:18 Then one of them, Cleopas, replied, "You must be the only person in Jerusalem who hasn't heard about all the things that have happened there the last few days."
눅 24:19 "What things?" Jesus asked. "The things that happened to Jesus, the man from Nazareth," they said. "He was a prophet who did powerful miracles, and he was a mighty teacher in the eyes of God and all the people.
눅 24:20 But our leading priests and other religious leaders handed him over to be condemned to death, and they crucified him.
눅 24:21 We had hoped he was the Messiah who had come to rescue Israel. This all happened three days ago.
눅 24:22 "Then some women from our group of his followers were at his tomb early this morning, and they came back with an amazing report.
눅 24:23 They said his body was missing, and they had seen angels who told them Jesus is alive!
눅 24:24 Some of our men ran out to see, and sure enough, his body was gone, just as the women had said."
눅 24:25 Then Jesus said to them, "You foolish people! You find it so hard to believe all that the prophets wrote in the Scriptures.
눅 24:26 Wasn't it clearly predicted that the Messiah would have to suffer all these things before entering his glory?"
눅 24:27 Then Jesus took them through the writings of Moses and all the prophets, explaining from all the Scriptures the things concerning himself.
눅 24:28 By this time they were nearing Emmaus and the end of their journey. Jesus acted as if he were going on,
눅 24:29 but they begged him, "Stay the night with us, since it is getting late." So he went home with them.
눅 24:30 As they sat down to eat①, he took the bread and blessed it. Then he broke it and gave it to them. / ①Or As they reclined
눅 24:31 Suddenly, their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And at that moment he disappeared!
눅 24:32 They said to each other, "Didn't our hearts burn within us as he talked with us on the road and explained the Scriptures to us?"
눅 24:33 And within the hour they were on their way back to Jerusalem. There they found the eleven disciples and the others who had gathered with them,
눅 24:34 who said, "The Lord has really risen! He appeared to Peter①." / ①Greek Simon
눅 24:35 Then the two from Emmaus told their story of how Jesus had appeared to them as they were walking along the road, and how they had recognized him as he was breaking the bread.
눅 24:36 And just as they were telling about it, Jesus himself was suddenly standing there among them. "Peace be with you," he said.
눅 24:37 But the whole group was startled and frightened, thinking they were seeing a ghost!
눅 24:38 "Why are you frightened?" he asked. "Why are your hearts filled with doubt?
눅 24:39 Look at my hands. Look at my feet. You can see that it's really me. Touch me and make sure that I am not a ghost, because ghosts don't have bodies, as you see that I do."
눅 24:40 As he spoke, he showed them his hands and his feet.
눅 24:41 Still they stood there in disbelief, filled with joy and wonder. Then he asked them, "Do you have anything here to eat?"
눅 24:42 They gave him a piece of broiled fish,
눅 24:43 and he ate it as they watched.
눅 24:44 Then he said, "When I was with you before, I told you that everything written about me in the law of Moses and the prophets and in the Psalms must be fulfilled."
눅 24:45 Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
눅 24:46 And he said, "Yes, it was written long ago that the Messiah would suffer and die and rise from the dead on the third day.
눅 24:47 It was also written that this message would be proclaimed in the authority of his name to all the nations①, beginning in Jerusalem： `There is forgiveness of sins for all who repent.' / ①Or all peoples
눅 24:48 You are witnesses of all these things.
눅 24:49 "And now I will send the Holy Spirit, just as my Father promised. But stay here in the city until the Holy Spirit comes and fills you with power from heaven."
눅 24:50 Then Jesus led them to Bethany, and lifting his hands to heaven, he blessed them.
눅 24:51 While he was blessing them, he left them and was taken up to heaven①. / ①Some manuscripts do not include and was taken up to heaven
눅 24:52 So they worshiped him and then returned to Jerusalem filled with great joy.
눅 24:53 And they spent all of their time in the Temple, praising God.
John
요 1:1 In the beginning the Word already existed The Word was with God, and the Word was God.
요 1:2 He existed in the beginning with God.
요 1:3 God created everything through him, and nothing was created except through him.
요 1:4 The Word gave life to everything that was created①, and his life brought light to everyone. / ①Or and nothing that was created was created except through him. The Word gave life to everything
요 1:5 The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness can never extinguish it①. / ①Or and the darkness has not understood it
요 1:6 God sent a man, John the Baptist①, / ①Greek a man named John
요 1:7 to tell about the light so that everyone might believe because of his testimony.
요 1:8 John himself was not the light; he was simply a witness to tell about the light.
요 1:9 The one who is the true light, who gives light to everyone, was coming into the world.
요 1:10 He came into the very world he created, but the world didn't recognize him.
요 1:11 He came to his own people, and even they rejected him.
요 1:12 But to all who believed him and accepted him, he gave the right to become children of God.
요 1:13 They are reborn?not with a physical birth resulting from human passion or plan, but a birth that comes from God.
요 1:14 So the Word became human① and made his home among us. He was full of unfailing love and faithfulness②. And we have seen his glory, the glory of the Father's one and only Son. / ①Greek became flesh ②Or grace and truth; also in 1.17
요 1:15 John testified about him when he shouted to the crowds, "This is the one I was talking about when I said, `Someone is coming after me who is far greater than I am, for he existed long before me.'"
요 1:16 From his abundance we have all received one gracious blessing after another①. / ①Or received the grace of Christ rather than the grace of the law; Greek reads received grace upon grace
요 1:17 For the law was given through Moses, but God's unfailing love and faithfulness came through Jesus Christ.
요 1:18 No one has ever seen God. But the unique One, who is himself God①, is near to the Father's heart. He has revealed God to us. / ①Some manuscripts read But the one and only Son
요 1:19 This was John's testimony when the Jewish leaders sent priests and Temple assistants① from Jerusalem to ask John, "Who are you?" / ①Greek and Levites
요 1:20 He came right out and said, "I am not the Messiah."
요 1:21 "Well then, who are you?" they asked. "Are you Elijah?" "No," he replied "Are you the Prophet we are expecting?"① "No." / ①Greek Are you the Prophet? See Deut 18.15, 18; Mal 4.5-6
요 1:22 "Then who are you? We need an answer for those who sent us. What do you have to say about yourself?"
요 1:23 John replied in the words of the prophet Isaiah： "I am a voice shouting in the wilderness, `Clear the way for the LORD's coming!'"① / ①Isa 40.3
요 1:24 Then the Pharisees who had been sent
요 1:25 asked him, "If you aren't the Messiah or Elijah or the Prophet, what right do you have to baptize?"
요 1:26 John told them, "I baptize with① water, but right here in the crowd is someone you do not recognize. / ①Or in; also in 1.31, 33
요 1:27 Though his ministry follows mine, I'm not even worthy to be his slave and untie the straps of his sandal."
요 1:28 This encounter took place in Bethany, an area east of the Jordan River, where John was baptizing.
요 1:29 The next day John saw Jesus coming toward him and said, "Look! The Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world!
요 1:30 He is the one I was talking about when I said, `A man is coming after me who is far greater than I am, for he existed long before me.'
요 1:31 I did not recognize him as the Messiah, but I have been baptizing with water so that he might be revealed to Israel."
요 1:32 Then John testified, "I saw the Holy Spirit descending like a dove from heaven and resting upon him.
요 1:33 I didn't know he was the one, but when God sent me to baptize with water, he told me, `The one on whom you see the Spirit descend and rest is the one who will baptize with the Holy Spirit.'
요 1:34 I saw this happen to Jesus, so I testify that he is the Chosen One of God①." / ①Some manuscripts read the Son of God
요 1:35 The following day John was again standing with two of his disciples.
요 1:36 As Jesus walked by, John looked at him and declared, "Look! There is the Lamb of God!"
요 1:37 When John's two disciples heard this, they followed Jesus.
요 1:38 Jesus looked around and saw them following. "What do you want?" he asked them They replied, "Rabbi" (which means "Teacher"), "where are you staying?"
요 1:39 "Come and see," he said. It was about four o'clock in the afternoon when they went with him to the place where he was staying, and they remained with him the rest of the day.
요 1:40 Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, was one of these men who heard what John said and then followed Jesus.
요 1:41 Andrew went to find his brother, Simon, and told him, "We have found the Messiah" (which means "Christ"①). / ①Christ means "the anointed one."
요 1:42 Then Andrew brought Simon to meet Jesus. Looking intently at Simon, Jesus said, "Your name is Simon, son of John - but you will be called Cephas" ①(which means "Peter"①). / ①The names Cephas (from Aramaic) and Peter (from Greek) both mean "rock."
요 1:43 The next day Jesus decided to go to Galilee. He found Philip and said to him, "Come, follow me."
요 1:44 Philip was from Bethsaida, Andrew and Peter's hometown.
요 1:45 Philip went to look for Nathanael and told him, "We have found the very person Moses① and the prophets wrote about! His name is Jesus, the son of Joseph from Nazareth." / ①Greek Moses in the law
요 1:46 "Nazareth!" exclaimed Nathanael. "Can anything good come from Nazareth?" "Come and see for yourself," Philip replied.
요 1:47 As they approached, Jesus said, "Now here is a genuine son of Israel?a man of complete integrity."
요 1:48 "How do you know about me?" Nathanael asked Jesus replied, "I could see you under the fig tree before Philip found you."
요 1:49 Then Nathanael exclaimed, "Rabbi, you are the Son of God?the King of Israel!"
요 1:50 Jesus asked him, "Do you believe this just because I told you I had seen you under the fig tree? You will see greater things than this."
요 1:51 Then he said, "I tell you the truth, you will all see heaven open and the angels of God going up and down on the Son of Man, the one who is the stairway between heaven and earth①." / ①Greek going up and down on the Son of Man; see Gen 28.10-17. "Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
요 2:1 The next day① there was a wedding celebration in the village of Cana in Galilee. Jesus' mother was there, / ①Greek On the third day; see 1.35, 43
요 2:2 and Jesus and his disciples were also invited to the celebration.
요 2:3 The wine supply ran out during the festivities, so Jesus' mother told him, "They have no more wine."
요 2:4 "Dear woman, that's not our problem," Jesus replied. "My time has not yet come."
요 2:5 But his mother told the servants, "Do whatever he tells you."
요 2:6 Standing nearby were six stone water jars, used for Jewish ceremonial washing. Each could hold twenty to thirty gallons①. / ①Greek 2 or 3 measures [75 to 113 liters]
요 2:7 Jesus told the servants, "Fill the jars with water." When the jars had been filled,
요 2:8 he said, "Now dip some out, and take it to the master of ceremonies." So the servants followed his instructions.
요 2:9 When the master of ceremonies tasted the water that was now wine, not knowing where it had come from (though, of course, the servants knew), he called the bridegroom over.
요 2:10 "A host always serves the best wine first," he said. "Then, when everyone has had a lot to drink, he brings out the less expensive wine. But you have kept the best until now!"
요 2:11 This miraculous sign at Cana in Galilee was the first time Jesus revealed his glory. And his disciples believed in him.
요 2:12 After the wedding he went to Capernaum for a few days with his mother, his brothers, and his disciples.
요 2:13 It was nearly time for the Jewish Passover celebration, so Jesus went to Jerusalem.
요 2:14 In the Temple area he saw merchants selling cattle, sheep, and doves for sacrifices; he also saw dealers at tables exchanging foreign money.
요 2:15 Jesus made a whip from some ropes and chased them all out of the Temple. He drove out the sheep and cattle, scattered the money changers' coins over the floor, and turned over their tables.
요 2:16 Then, going over to the people who sold doves, he told them, "Get these things out of here. Stop turning my Father's house into a marketplace!"
요 2:17 Then his disciples remembered this prophecy from the Scriptures： "Passion for God's house will consume me."① / ①Or "Concern for God's house will be my undoing." Ps 69.9
요 2:18 But the Jewish leaders demanded, "What are you doing? If God gave you authority to do this, show us a miraculous sign to prove it."
요 2:19 "All right," Jesus replied. "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up."
요 2:20 "What!" they exclaimed. "It has taken forty-six years to build this Temple, and you can rebuild it in three days?"
요 2:21 But when Jesus said "this temple," he meant his own body.
요 2:22 After he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered he had said this, and they believed both the Scriptures and what Jesus had said.
요 2:23 Because of the miraculous signs Jesus did in Jerusalem at the Passover celebration, many began to trust in him.
요 2:24 But Jesus didn't trust them, because he knew human nature.
요 2:25 No one needed to tell him what mankind is really like.
요 3:1 There was a man named Nicodemus, a Jewish religious leader who was a Pharisee.
요 3:2 After dark one evening, he came to speak with Jesus. "Rabbi," he said, "we all know that God has sent you to teach us. Your miraculous signs are evidence that God is with you."
요 3:3 Jesus replied, "I tell you the truth, unless you are born again①, you cannot see the Kingdom of God." / ①Or born from above; also in 3.7
요 3:4 "What do you mean?" exclaimed Nicodemus. "How can an old man go back into his mother's womb and be born again?"
요 3:5 Jesus replied, "I assure you, no one can enter the Kingdom of God without being born of water and the Spirit①. / ①Or and spirit. The Greek word for Spirit can also be translated wind; see 3.8
요 3:6 Humans can reproduce only human life, but the Holy Spirit gives birth to spiritual life①. / ①Greek what is born of the Spirit is spirit
요 3:7 So don't be surprised when I say, `You① must be born again.' / ①The Greek word for you is plural; also in 3.12
요 3:8 The wind blows wherever it wants. Just as you can hear the wind but can't tell where it comes from or where it is going, so you can't explain how people are born of the Spirit."
요 3:9 "How are these things possible?" Nicodemus asked.
요 3:10 Jesus replied, "You are a respected Jewish teacher, and yet you don't understand these things?
요 3:11 I assure you, we tell you what we know and have seen, and yet you won't believe our testimony.
요 3:12 But if you don't believe me when I tell you about earthly things, how can you possibly believe if I tell you about heavenly things?
요 3:13 No one has ever gone to heaven and returned. But the Son of Man① has come down from heaven. / ①Some manuscripts add who lives in heaven. "Son of Man" is a title Jesus used for himself
