요 17:24 Father, I want these whom you have given me to be with me where I am. Then they can see all the glory you gave me because you loved me even before the world began!
요 17:25 "O righteous Father, the world doesn't know you, but I do; and these disciples know you sent me.
요 17:26 I have revealed you to them, and I will continue to do so. Then your love for me will be in them, and I will be in them."
요 18:1 After saying these things, Jesus crossed the Kidron Valley with his disciples and entered a grove of olive trees.
요 18:2 Judas, the betrayer, knew this place, because Jesus had often gone there with his disciples.
요 18:3 The leading priests and Pharisees had given Judas a contingent of Roman soldiers and Temple guards to accompany him. Now with blazing torches, lanterns, and weapons, they arrived at the olive grove.
요 18:4 Jesus fully realized all that was going to happen to him, so he stepped forward to meet them. "Who are you looking for?" he asked.
요 18:5 "Jesus the Nazarene,"① they replied. "I AM he,"② Jesus said. (Judas, who betrayed him, was standing with them.) / ①Or Jesus of Nazareth; also in 18.7
요 18:6 As Jesus said "I AM he," they all drew back and fell to the ground! ②Or "The `I AM' is here"; or "I am the LORD"; Greek reads I am; also in 18.6, 8. See Exod 3.14
요 18:7 Once more he asked them, "Who are you looking for?" And again they replied, "Jesus the Nazarene."
요 18:8 "I told you that I AM he," Jesus said. "And since I am the one you want, let these others go."
요 18:9 He did this to fulfill his own statement： "I did not lose a single one of those you have given me."① / ①See John 6.39 and 17.12
요 18:10 Then Simon Peter drew a sword and slashed off the right ear of Malchus, the high priest's slave.
요 18:11 But Jesus said to Peter, "Put your sword back into its sheath. Shall I not drink from the cup of suffering the Father has given me?"
요 18:12 So the soldiers, their commanding officer, and the Temple guards arrested Jesus and tied him up.
요 18:13 First they took him to Annas, the father-in-law of Caiaphas, the high priest at that time①. / ①Greek that year
요 18:14 Caiaphas was the one who had told the other Jewish leaders, "It's better that one man should die for the people."
요 18:15 Simon Peter followed Jesus, as did another of the disciples. That other disciple was acquainted with the high priest, so he was allowed to enter the high priest's courtyard with Jesus.
요 18:16 Peter had to stay outside the gate. Then the disciple who knew the high priest spoke to the woman watching at the gate, and she let Peter in.
요 18:17 The woman asked Peter, "You're not one of that man's disciples, are you?" "No," he said, "I am not."
요 18:18 Because it was cold, the household servants and the guards had made a charcoal fire. They stood around it, warming themselves, and Peter stood with them, warming himself.
요 18:19 Inside, the high priest began asking Jesus about his followers and what he had been teaching them.
요 18:20 Jesus replied, "Everyone knows what I teach. I have preached regularly in the synagogues and the Temple, where the people① gather. I have not spoken in secret. / ①Greek Jewish people; also in 18.38
요 18:21 Why are you asking me this question? Ask those who heard me. They know what I said."
요 18:22 Then one of the Temple guards standing nearby slapped Jesus across the face. "Is that the way to answer the high priest?" he demanded.
요 18:23 Jesus replied, "If I said anything wrong, you must prove it. But if I'm speaking the truth, why are you beating me?"
요 18:24 Then Annas bound Jesus and sent him to Caiaphas, the high priest.
요 18:25 Meanwhile, as Simon Peter was standing by the fire warming himself, they asked him again, "You're not one of his disciples, are you?" He denied it, saying, "No, I am not."
요 18:26 But one of the household slaves of the high priest, a relative of the man whose ear Peter had cut off, asked, "Didn't I see you out there in the olive grove with Jesus?"
요 18:27 Again Peter denied it. And immediately a rooster crowed.
요 18:28 Jesus' trial before Caiaphas ended in the early hours of the morning. Then he was taken to the headquarters of the Roman governor①. His accusers didn't go inside because it would defile them, and they wouldn't be allowed to celebrate the Passover. / ①Greek to the Praetorium; also in 18.33
요 18:29 So Pilate, the governor, went out to them and asked, "What is your charge against this man?"
요 18:30 "We wouldn't have handed him over to you if he weren't a criminal!" they retorted.
요 18:31 "Then take him away and judge him by your own law," Pilate told them. "Only the Romans are permitted to execute someone," the Jewish leaders replied.
요 18:32 (This fulfilled Jesus' prediction about the way he would die①.) / ①See John 12.32-33
요 18:33 Then Pilate went back into his headquarters and called for Jesus to be brought to him. "Are you the king of the Jews?" he asked him.
요 18:34 Jesus replied, "Is this your own question, or did others tell you about me?"
요 18:35 "Am I a Jew?" Pilate retorted. "Your own people and their leading priests brought you to me for trial. Why? What have you done?"
요 18:36 Jesus answered, "My Kingdom is not an earthly kingdom. If it were, my followers would fight to keep me from being handed over to the Jewish leaders. But my Kingdom is not of this world."
요 18:37 Pilate said, "So you are a king?" Jesus responded, "You say I am a king. Actually, I was born and came into the world to testify to the truth. All who love the truth recognize that what I say is true."
요 18:38 "What is truth?" Pilate asked. Then he went out again to the people and told them, "He is not guilty of any crime.
요 18:39 But you have a custom of asking me to release one prisoner each year at Passover. Would you like me to release this `King of the Jews'?"
요 18:40 But they shouted back, "No! Not this man. We want Barabbas!" ① / ①Barabbas was a revolutionary
요 19:1 Then Pilate had Jesus flogged with a lead-tipped whip.
요 19:2 The soldiers wove a crown of thorns and put it on his head, and they put a purple robe on him.
요 19:3 "Hail! King of the Jews!" they mocked, as they slapped him across the face.
요 19:4 Pilate went outside again and said to the people, "I am going to bring him out to you now, but understand clearly that I find him not guilty."
요 19:5 Then Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe. And Pilate said, "Look, here is the man!"
요 19:6 When they saw him, the leading priests and Temple guards began shouting, "Crucify him! Crucify him!" "Take him yourselves and crucify him," Pilate said. "I find him not guilty."
요 19:7 The Jewish leaders replied, "By our law he ought to die because he called himself the Son of God."
요 19:8 When Pilate heard this, he was more frightened than ever.
요 19:9 He took Jesus back into the headquarters① again and asked him, "Where are you from?" But Jesus gave no answer. / ①Greek the Praetorium
요 19:10 "Why don't you talk to me?" Pilate demanded. "Don't you realize that I have the power to release you or crucify you?"
요 19:11 Then Jesus said, "You would have no power over me at all unless it were given to you from above. So the one who handed me over to you has the greater sin."
요 19:12 Then Pilate tried to release him, but the Jewish leaders shouted, "If you release this man, you are no `friend of Caesar.'① Anyone who declares himself a king is a rebel against Caesar." / ①"Friend of Caesar" is a technical term that refers to an ally of the emperor
요 19:13 When they said this, Pilate brought Jesus out to them again. Then Pilate sat down on the judgment seat on the platform that is called the Stone Pavement①. / ①in Hebrew, Gabbatha
요 19:14 It was now about noon on the day of preparation for the Passover. And Pilate said to the people①, "Look, here is your king!" / ①Greek Jewish people; also in 19.20
요 19:15 "Away with him," they yelled. "Away with him! Crucify him!" "What? Crucify your king?" Pilate asked. "We have no king but Caesar," the leading priests shouted back.
요 19:16 Then Pilate turned Jesus over to them to be crucified. So they took Jesus away.
요 19:17 Carrying the cross by himself, he went to the place called Place of the Skull①. / ①in Hebrew, Golgotha
요 19:18 There they nailed him to the cross. Two others were crucified with him, one on either side, with Jesus between them.
요 19:19 And Pilate posted a sign over him that read, "Jesus of Nazareth①, the King of the Jews." / ①Or Jesus the Nazarene
요 19:20 The place where Jesus was crucified was near the city, and the sign was written in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek, so that many people could read it.
요 19:21 Then the leading priests objected and said to Pilate, "Change it from `The King of the Jews' to `He said, I am King of the Jews.'"
요 19:22 Pilate replied, "No, what I have written, I have written."
요 19:23 When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they divided his clothes among the four of them. They also took his robe, but it was seamless, woven in one piece from top to bottom.
요 19:24 So they said, "Rather than tearing it apart, let's throw dice① for it." This fulfilled the Scripture that says, "They divided my garments among themselves and threw dice for my clothing."② So that is what they did. / ①Greek cast lots ②Ps 22.18
요 19:25 Standing near the cross were Jesus' mother, and his mother's sister, Mary (the wife of Clopas), and Mary Magdalene.
요 19:26 When Jesus saw his mother standing there beside the disciple he loved, he said to her, "Dear woman, here is your son."
요 19:27 And he said to this disciple, "Here is your mother." And from then on this disciple took her into his home.
요 19:28 Jesus knew that his mission was now finished, and to fulfill Scripture he said, "I am thirsty."① / ①See Pss 22.15; 69.21
요 19:29 A jar of sour wine was sitting there, so they soaked a sponge in it, put it on a hyssop branch, and held it up to his lips.
요 19:30 When Jesus had tasted it, he said, "It is finished!" Then he bowed his head and released his spirit.
요 19:31 It was the day of preparation, and the Jewish leaders didn't want the bodies hanging there the next day, which was the Sabbath ①. So they asked Pilate to hasten their deaths by ordering that their legs be broken. Then their bodies could be taken down. / ①and a very special Sabbath, because it was the Passover
요 19:32 So the soldiers came and broke the legs of the two men crucified with Jesus.
요 19:33 But when they came to Jesus, they saw that he was already dead, so they didn't break his legs.
요 19:34 One of the soldiers, however, pierced his side with a spear, and immediately blood and water flowed out.
요 19:35 (This report is from an eyewitness giving an accurate account. He speaks the truth so that you also can believe①.) / ①Some manuscripts read can continue to believe
요 19:36 These things happened in fulfillment of the Scriptures that say, "Not one of his bones will be broken,"① / ①Exod 12.46; Num 9.12; Ps 34.20
요 19:37 and "They will look on the one they pierced."① / ①Zech 12.10
요 19:38 Afterward Joseph of Arimathea, who had been a secret disciple of Jesus (because he feared the Jewish leaders), asked Pilate for permission to take down Jesus' body. When Pilate gave permission, Joseph came and took the body away.
요 19:39 With him came Nicodemus, the man who had come to Jesus at night. He brought seventy-five pounds① of perfumed ointment made from myrrh and aloes. / ①Greek 100 litras [32.7 kilograms]
요 19:40 Following Jewish burial custom, they wrapped Jesus' body with the spices in long sheets of linen cloth.
요 19:41 The place of crucifixion was near a garden, where there was a new tomb, never used before.
요 19:42 And so, because it was the day of preparation for the Jewish Passover① and since the tomb was close at hand, they laid Jesus there. / ①Greek because of the Jewish day of preparation
요 20:1 Early on Sunday morning①, while it was still dark, Mary Magdalene came to the tomb and found that the stone had been rolled away from the entrance. / ①Greek On the first day of the week.
요 20:2 She ran and found Simon Peter and the other disciple, the one whom Jesus loved. She said, "They have taken the Lord's body out of the tomb, and we don't know where they have put him!"
요 20:3 Peter and the other disciple started out for the tomb.
요 20:4 They were both running, but the other disciple outran Peter and reached the tomb first.
요 20:5 He stooped and looked in and saw the linen wrappings lying there, but he didn't go in.
요 20:6 Then Simon Peter arrived and went inside. He also noticed the linen wrappings lying there,
요 20:7 while the cloth that had covered Jesus' head was folded up and lying apart from the other wrappings.
요 20:8 Then the disciple who had reached the tomb first also went in, and he saw and believed?
요 20:9 for until then they still hadn't understood the Scriptures that said Jesus must rise from the dead.
요 20:10 Then they went home.
요 20:11 Mary was standing outside the tomb crying, and as she wept, she stooped and looked in.
요 20:12 She saw two white-robed angels, one sitting at the head and the other at the foot of the place where the body of Jesus had been lying.
요 20:13 "Dear woman, why are you crying?" the angels asked her. "Because they have taken away my Lord," she replied, "and I don't know where they have put him."
요 20:14 She turned to leave and saw someone standing there. It was Jesus, but she didn't recognize him.
요 20:15 "Dear woman, why are you crying?" Jesus asked her. "Who are you looking for?" She thought he was the gardener. "Sir," she said, "if you have taken him away, tell me where you have put him, and I will go and get him."
요 20:16 "Mary!" Jesus said. She turned to him and cried out, "Rabboni!" (which is Hebrew for "Teacher").
요 20:17 "Don't cling to me," Jesus said, "for I haven't yet ascended to the Father. But go find my brothers and tell them, `I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.'"
요 20:18 Mary Magdalene found the disciples and told them, "I have seen the Lord!" Then she gave them his message.
요 20:19 That Sunday evening① the disciples were meeting behind locked doors because they were afraid of the Jewish leaders. Suddenly, Jesus was standing there among them! "Peace be with you," he said. / ①Greek In the evening of that day, the first day of the week.
요 20:20 As he spoke, he showed them the wounds in his hands and his side. They were filled with joy when they saw the Lord!
요 20:21 Again he said, "Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, so I am sending you."
요 20:22 Then he breathed on them and said, "Receive the Holy Spirit.
요 20:23 If you forgive anyone's sins, they are forgiven. If you do not forgive them, they are not forgiven."
요 20:24 One of the twelve disciples, Thomas (nicknamed the Twin)①, was not with the others when Jesus came. / ①Greek Thomas, who was called Didymus
요 20:25 They told him, "We have seen the Lord!" But he replied, "I won't believe it unless I see the nail wounds in his hands, put my fingers into them, and place my hand into the wound in his side."
요 20:26 Eight days later the disciples were together again, and this time Thomas was with them. The doors were locked; but suddenly, as before, Jesus was standing among them. "Peace be with you," he said.
요 20:27 Then he said to Thomas, "Put your finger here, and look at my hands. Put your hand into the wound in my side. Don't be faithless any longer. Believe!"
요 20:28 "My Lord and my God!" Thomas exclaimed.
요 20:29 Then Jesus told him, "You believe because you have seen me. Blessed are those who believe without seeing me."
요 20:30 The disciples saw Jesus do many other miraculous signs in addition to the ones recorded in this book.
요 20:31 But these are written so that you may continue to believe① that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that by believing in him you will have life by the power of his name. / ①Some manuscripts read that you may believe
요 21:1 Later, Jesus appeared again to the disciples beside the Sea of Galilee①. This is how it happened. / ①Greek Sea of Tiberias, another name for the Sea of Galilee
요 21:2 Several of the disciples were there - Simon Peter, Thomas (nicknamed the Twin)①, Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two other disciples. / ①Greek Thomas, who was called Didymus
요 21:3 Simon Peter said, "I'm going fishing." "We'll come, too," they all said. So they went out in the boat, but they caught nothing all night.
요 21:4 At dawn Jesus was standing on the beach, but the disciples couldn't see who he was.
요 21:5 He called out, "Fellows①, have you caught any fish?" "No," they replied. / ①Greek Children
요 21:6 Then he said, "Throw out your net on the right-hand side of the boat, and you'll get some!" So they did, and they couldn't haul in the net because there were so many fish in it.
요 21:7 Then the disciple Jesus loved said to Peter, "It's the Lord!" When Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he put on his tunic (for he had stripped for work), jumped into the water, and headed to shore.
요 21:8 The others stayed with the boat and pulled the loaded net to the shore, for they were only about a hundred yards① from shore. / ①Greek 200 cubits [90 meters]
요 21:9 When they got there, they found breakfast waiting for them?fish cooking over a charcoal fire, and some bread.
요 21:10 "Bring some of the fish you've just caught," Jesus said.
요 21:11 So Simon Peter went aboard and dragged the net to the shore. There were 153 large fish, and yet the net hadn't torn.
요 21:12 "Now come and have some breakfast!" Jesus said. None of the disciples dared to ask him, "Who are you?" They knew it was the Lord.
요 21:13 Then Jesus served them the bread and the fish.
요 21:14 This was the third time Jesus had appeared to his disciples since he had been raised from the dead.
요 21:15 After breakfast Jesus asked Simon Peter, "Simon son of John, do you love me more than these?①" "Yes, Lord," Peter replied, "you know I love you." "Then feed my lambs," Jesus told him. / ①Or more than these others do?
요 21:16 Jesus repeated the question： "Simon son of John, do you love me?" "Yes, Lord," Peter said, "you know I love you." "Then take care of my sheep," Jesus said.
요 21:17 A third time he asked him, "Simon son of John, do you love me?" Peter was hurt that Jesus asked the question a third time. He said, "Lord, you know everything. You know that I love you." Jesus said, "Then feed my sheep.
요 21:18 "I tell you the truth, when you were young, you were able to do as you liked; you dressed yourself and went wherever you wanted to go. But when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and others① will dress you and take you where you don't want to go." / ①Some manuscripts read and another one
요 21:19 Jesus said this to let him know by what kind of death he would glorify God. Then Jesus told him, "Follow me."
요 21:20 Peter turned around and saw behind them the disciple Jesus loved?the one who had leaned over to Jesus during supper and asked, "Lord, who will betray you?"
요 21:21 Peter asked Jesus, "What about him, Lord?"
요 21:22 Jesus replied, "If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you? As for you, follow me."
요 21:23 So the rumor spread among the community of believers① that this disciple wouldn't die. But that isn't what Jesus said at all. He only said, "If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you?" / ①Greek the brothers
요 21:24 This disciple is the one who testifies to these events and has recorded them here. And we know that his account of these things is accurate.
요 21:25 Jesus also did many other things. If they were all written down, I suppose the whole world could not contain the books that would be written.

행 1:5 John baptized with① water, but in just a few days you will be baptized with① the Holy Spirit." / ①Or in

행 1:7 He replied, "The Father alone has the authority to set those dates and times, and they are not for you to know.
행 1:8 But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes upon you. And you will be my witnesses, telling people about me everywhere?in Jerusalem, throughout Judea, in Samaria, and to the ends of the earth."
행 1:9 After saying this, he was taken up into a cloud while they were watching, and they could no longer see him.
행 1:10 As they strained to see him rising into heaven, two white-robed men suddenly stood among them.
행 1:11 "Men of Galilee," they said, "why are you standing here staring into heaven? Jesus has been taken from you into heaven, but someday he will return from heaven in the same way you saw him go!"

행 1:13 When they arrived, they went to the upstairs room of the house where they were staying. Here are the names of those who were present： Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James (son of Alphaeus), Simon (the Zealot), and Judas (son of James).
행 1:14 They all met together and were constantly united in prayer, along with Mary the mother of Jesus, several other women, and the brothers of Jesus.

행 1:16 "Brothers," he said, "the Scriptures had to be fulfilled concerning Judas, who guided those who arrested Jesus. This was predicted long ago by the Holy Spirit, speaking through King David.
행 1:17 Judas was one of us and shared in the ministry with us."
행 1:18 (Judas had bought a field with the money he received for his treachery. Falling headfirst there, his body split open, spilling out all his intestines.
행 1:19 The news of his death spread to all the people of Jerusalem, and they gave the place the Aramaic name Akeldama, which means "Field of Blood.")
행 1:20 Peter continued, "This was written in the book of Psalms, where it says, `Let his home become desolate, with no one living in it.' It also says, `Let someone else take his position.'① / ①Pss 69.25; 109.8
행 1:21 "So now we must choose a replacement for Judas from among the men who were with us the entire time we were traveling with the Lord Jesus?
행 1:22 from the time he was baptized by John until the day he was taken from us. Whoever is chosen will join us as a witness of Jesus' resurrection."
행 1:23 So they nominated two men： Joseph called Barsabbas (also known as Justus) and Matthias.
행 1:24 Then they all prayed, "O Lord, you know every heart. Show us which of these men you have chosen
행 1:25 as an apostle to replace Judas in this ministry, for he has deserted us and gone where he belongs."
행 1:26 Then they cast lots, and Matthias was selected to become an apostle with the other eleven.

행 2:3 Then, what looked like flames or tongues of fire appeared and settled on each of them.

행 2:5 At that time there were devout Jews from every nation living in Jerusalem.
행 2:6 When they heard the loud noise, everyone came running, and they were bewildered to hear their own languages being spoken by the believers.

행 2:8 and yet we hear them speaking in our own native languages!

행 2:11 (both Jews and converts to Judaism), Cretans, and Arabs. And we all hear these people speaking in our own languages about the wonderful things God has done!"

행 2:16 No, what you see was predicted long ago by the prophet Joel.

행 2:23 But God knew what would happen, and his prearranged plan was carried out when Jesus was betrayed. With the help of lawless Gentiles, you nailed him to a cross and killed him.
행 2:24 But God released him from the horrors of death and raised him back to life, for death could not keep him in its grip.
행 2:25 King David said this about him： `I see that the LORD is always with me I will not be shaken, for he is right beside me.
행 2:26 No wonder my heart is glad, and my tongue shouts his praises! My body rests in hope.
행 2:27 For you will not leave my soul among the dead① or allow your Holy One to rot in the grave. / ①Greek in Hades

행 3:3 When he saw Peter and John about to enter, he asked them for some money.
행 3:4 Peter and John looked at him intently, and Peter said, "Look at us!"

행 3:9 All the people saw him walking and heard him praising God.
행 3:10 When they realized he was the lame beggar they had seen so often at the Beautiful Gate, they were absolutely astounded!
행 3:11 They all rushed out in amazement to Solomon's Colonnade, where the man was holding tightly to Peter and John.

행 3:14 You rejected this holy, righteous one and instead demanded the release of a murderer.

행 3:20 Then times of refreshment will come from the presence of the Lord, and he will again send you Jesus, your appointed Messiah.

행 4:1 While Peter and John were speaking to the people, they were confronted by the priests, the captain of the Temple guard, and some of the Sadducees.
행 4:2 These leaders were very disturbed that Peter and John were teaching the people that through Jesus there is a resurrection of the dead.
행 4:3 They arrested them and, since it was already evening, put them in jail until morning.
행 4:4 But many of the people who heard their message believed it, so the number of believers now totaled about 5,000 men, not counting women and children①. / ①Greek 5,000 adult males
행 4:5 The next day the council of all the rulers and elders and teachers of religious law met in Jerusalem.
행 4:6 Annas the high priest was there, along with Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and other relatives of the high priest.
행 4:7 They brought in the two disciples and demanded, "By what power, or in whose name, have you done this?"
행 4:8 Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, "Rulers and elders of our people,
행 4:9 are we being questioned today because we've done a good deed for a crippled man? Do you want to know how he was healed?
행 4:10 Let me clearly state to all of you and to all the people of Israel that he was healed by the powerful name of Jesus Christ the Nazarene①, the man you crucified but whom God raised from the dead. / ①Or Jesus Christ of Nazareth
행 4:11 For Jesus is the one referred to in the Scriptures, where it says, `The stone that you builders rejected has now become the cornerstone.'① / ①Ps 118.22
행 4:12 There is salvation in no one else! God has given no other name under heaven by which we must be saved."
행 4:13 The members of the council were amazed when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, for they could see that they were ordinary men with no special training in the Scriptures. They also recognized them as men who had been with Jesus.
행 4:14 But since they could see the man who had been healed standing right there among them, there was nothing the council could say.
행 4:15 So they ordered Peter and John out of the council chamber① and conferred among themselves. / ①Greek the Sanhedrin
행 4:16 "What should we do with these men?" they asked each other. "We can't deny that they have performed a miraculous sign, and everybody in Jerusalem knows about it.
행 4:17 But to keep them from spreading their propaganda any further, we must warn them not to speak to anyone in Jesus' name again."
행 4:18 So they called the apostles back in and commanded them never again to speak or teach in the name of Jesus.
행 4:19 But Peter and John replied, "Do you think God wants us to obey you rather than him?
행 4:20 We cannot stop telling about everything we have seen and heard."
행 4:21 The council then threatened them further, but they finally let them go because they didn't know how to punish them without starting a riot. For everyone was praising God
행 4:22 for this miraculous sign?the healing of a man who had been lame for more than forty years.
행 4:23 As soon as they were freed, Peter and John returned to the other believers and told them what the leading priests and elders had said.
행 4:24 When they heard the report, all the believers lifted their voices together in prayer to God： "O Sovereign Lord, Creator of heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them?
행 4:25 you spoke long ago by the Holy Spirit through our ancestor David, your servant, saying, `Why were the nations so angry? Why did they waste their time with futile plans?
행 4:26 The kings of the earth prepared for battle; the rulers gathered together against the LORD and against his Messiah.'① / ①Or his anointed one; or his Christ. Ps 2.1-2
행 4:27 "In fact, this has happened here in this very city! For Herod Antipas, Pontius Pilate the governor, the Gentiles, and the people of Israel were all united against Jesus, your holy servant, whom you anointed.
행 4:28 But everything they did was determined beforehand according to your will.
행 4:29 And now, O Lord, hear their threats, and give us, your servants, great boldness in preaching your word.
행 4:30 Stretch out your hand with healing power; may miraculous signs and wonders be done through the name of your holy servant Jesus."
행 4:31 After this prayer, the meeting place shook, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit. Then they preached the word of God with boldness.
행 4:32 All the believers were united in heart and mind. And they felt that what they owned was not their own, so they shared everything they had.
행 4:33 The apostles testified powerfully to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and God's great blessing was upon them all.
행 4:34 There were no needy people among them, because those who owned land or houses would sell them
행 4:35 and bring the money to the apostles to give to those in need.
행 4:36 For instance, there was Joseph, the one the apostles nicknamed Barnabas (which means "Son of Encouragement"). He was from the tribe of Levi and came from the island of Cyprus.
행 4:37 He sold a field he owned and brought the money to the apostles.
행 5:1 But there was a certain man named Ananias who, with his wife, Sapphira, sold some property.
행 5:2 He brought part of the money to the apostles, claiming it was the full amount. With his wife's consent, he kept the rest.
행 5:3 Then Peter said, "Ananias, why have you let Satan fill your heart? You lied to the Holy Spirit, and you kept some of the money for yourself.
행 5:4 The property was yours to sell or not sell, as you wished. And after selling it, the money was also yours to give away. How could you do a thing like this? You weren't lying to us but to God!"
행 5:5 As soon as Ananias heard these words, he fell to the floor and died. Everyone who heard about it was terrified.
행 5:6 Then some young men got up, wrapped him in a sheet, and took him out and buried him.
행 5:7 About three hours later his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.
행 5:8 Peter asked her, "Was this the price you and your husband received for your land?" "Yes," she replied, "that was the price."
행 5:9 And Peter said, "How could the two of you even think of conspiring to test the Spirit of the Lord like this? The young men who buried your husband are just outside the door, and they will carry you out, too."
행 5:10 Instantly, she fell to the floor and died. When the young men came in and saw that she was dead, they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
행 5:11 Great fear gripped the entire church and everyone else who heard what had happened.
행 5:12 The apostles were performing many miraculous signs and wonders among the people. And all the believers were meeting regularly at the Temple in the area known as Solomon's Colonnade.
행 5:13 But no one else dared to join them, even though all the people had high regard for them.
행 5:14 Yet more and more people believed and were brought to the Lord?crowds of both men and women.
행 5:15 As a result of the apostles' work, sick people were brought out into the streets on beds and mats so that Peter's shadow might fall across some of them as he went by.
행 5:16 Crowds came from the villages around Jerusalem, bringing their sick and those possessed by evil① spirits, and they were all healed. / ①Greek unclean
행 5:17 The high priest and his officials, who were Sadducees, were filled with jealousy.
행 5:18 They arrested the apostles and put them in the public jail.
행 5:19 But an angel of the Lord came at night, opened the gates of the jail, and brought them out. Then he told them,
행 5:20 "Go to the Temple and give the people this message of life!"
행 5:21 So at daybreak the apostles entered the Temple, as they were told, and immediately began teachingWhen the high priest and his officials arrived, they convened the high council① - the full assembly of the elders of Israel. Then they sent for the apostles to be brought from the jail for trial. / ①Greek Sanhedrin; also in 5.27, 41
행 5:22 But when the Temple guards went to the jail, the men were gone. So they returned to the council and reported,
행 5:23 "The jail was securely locked, with the guards standing outside, but when we opened the gates, no one was there!"
행 5:24 When the captain of the Temple guard and the leading priests heard this, they were perplexed, wondering where it would all end.
행 5:25 Then someone arrived with startling news： "The men you put in jail are standing in the Temple, teaching the people!"
행 5:26 The captain went with his Temple guards and arrested the apostles, but without violence, for they were afraid the people would stone them.
행 5:27 Then they brought the apostles before the high council, where the high priest confronted them.
행 5:28 "Didn't we tell you never again to teach in this man's name?" he demanded. "Instead, you have filled all Jerusalem with your teaching about him, and you want to make us responsible for his death!"
행 5:29 But Peter and the apostles replied, "We must obey God rather than any human authority.
행 5:30 The God of our ancestors raised Jesus from the dead after you killed him by hanging him on a cross①. / ①Greek on a tree
행 5:31 Then God put him in the place of honor at his right hand as Prince and Savior. He did this so the people of Israel would repent of their sins and be forgiven.
행 5:32 We are witnesses of these things and so is the Holy Spirit, who is given by God to those who obey him."
행 5:33 When they heard this, the high council was furious and decided to kill them.
행 5:34 But one member, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, who was an expert in religious law and respected by all the people, stood up and ordered that the men be sent outside the council chamber for a while.
행 5:35 Then he said to his colleagues, "Men of Israel, take care what you are planning to do to these men!
행 5:36 Some time ago there was that fellow Theudas, who pretended to be someone great. About 400 others joined him, but he was killed, and all his followers went their various ways. The whole movement came to nothing.
행 5:37 After him, at the time of the census, there was Judas of Galilee. He got people to follow him, but he was killed, too, and all his followers were scattered.
행 5:38 "So my advice is, leave these men alone. Let them go. If they are planning and doing these things merely on their own, it will soon be overthrown.
행 5:39 But if it is from God, you will not be able to overthrow them. You may even find yourselves fighting against God!"
행 5:40 The others accepted his advice. They called in the apostles and had them flogged. Then they ordered them never again to speak in the name of Jesus, and they let them go.
행 5:41 The apostles left the high council rejoicing that God had counted them worthy to suffer disgrace for the name of Jesus①. / ①Greek for the name
행 5:42 And every day, in the Temple and from house to house, they continued to teach and preach this message： "Jesus is the Messiah."
행 6:1 But as the believers① rapidly multiplied, there were rumblings of discontent. The Greek-speaking believers complained about the Hebrew-speaking believers, saying that their widows were being discriminated against in the daily distribution of food. / ①Greek disciples; also in 6.2, 7
행 6:2 So the Twelve called a meeting of all the believers. They said, "We apostles should spend our time teaching the word of God, not running a food program.
행 6:3 And so, brothers, select seven men who are well respected and are full of the Spirit and wisdom. We will give them this responsibility.
행 6:4 Then we apostles can spend our time in prayer and teaching the word."
행 6:5 Everyone liked this idea, and they chose the following： Stephen (a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit), Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas of Antioch (an earlier convert to the Jewish faith).
행 6:6 These seven were presented to the apostles, who prayed for them as they laid their hands on them.
행 6:7 So God's message continued to spread. The number of believers greatly increased in Jerusalem, and many of the Jewish priests were converted, too.
행 6:8 Stephen, a man full of God's grace and power, performed amazing miracles and signs among the people.
행 6:9 But one day some men from the Synagogue of Freed Slaves, as it was called, started to debate with him. They were Jews from Cyrene, Alexandria, Cilicia, and the province of Asia.
행 6:10 None of them could stand against the wisdom and the Spirit with which Stephen spoke.
행 6:11 So they persuaded some men to lie about Stephen, saying, "We heard him blaspheme Moses, and even God."
행 6:12 This roused the people, the elders, and the teachers of religious law. So they arrested Stephen and brought him before the high council①. / ①Greek Sanhedrin
행 6:13 The lying witnesses said, "This man is always speaking against the holy Temple and against the law of Moses.
행 6:14 We have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth① will destroy the Temple and change the customs Moses handed down to us." / ①Or Jesus the Nazarene
행 6:15 At this point everyone in the high council① stared at Stephen, because his face became as bright as an angel's. / ①Greek Sanhedrin
행 7:1 Then the high priest asked Stephen, "Are these accusations true?"
행 7:2 This was Stephen's reply： "Brothers and fathers, listen to me. Our glorious God appeared to our ancestor Abraham in Mesopotamia before he settled in Haran①. / ①Mesopotamia was the region now called Iraq. Haran was a city in what is now called Syria
행 7:3 God told him, `Leave your native land and your relatives, and come into the land that I will show you.'① / ①Gen 12.1
행 7:4 So Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and lived in Haran until his father died. Then God brought him here to the land where you now live.
행 7:5 "But God gave him no inheritance here, not even one square foot of land. God did promise, however, that eventually the whole land would belong to Abraham and his descendants?even though he had no children yet.
행 7:6 God also told him that his descendants would live in a foreign land, where they would be oppressed as slaves for 400 years.
행 7:7 `But I will punish the nation that enslaves them,' God said, `and in the end they will come out and worship me here in this place.'① / ①Gen 12.7; 15.13-14; Exod 3.12
행 7:8 "God also gave Abraham the covenant of circumcision at that time. So when Abraham became the father of Isaac, he circumcised him on the eighth day. And the practice was continued when Isaac became the father of Jacob, and when Jacob became the father of the twelve patriarchs of the Israelite nation.
행 7:9 "These patriarchs were jealous of their brother Joseph, and they sold him to be a slave in Egypt. But God was with him
행 7:10 and rescued him from all his troubles. And God gave him favor before Pharaoh, king of Egypt. God also gave Joseph unusual wisdom, so that Pharaoh appointed him governor over all of Egypt and put him in charge of the palace.
행 7:11 "But a famine came upon Egypt and Canaan. There was great misery, and our ancestors ran out of food.
행 7:12 Jacob heard that there was still grain in Egypt, so he sent his sons?our ancestors?to buy some.
행 7:13 The second time they went, Joseph revealed his identity to his brothers①, and they were introduced to Pharaoh. / ①Other manuscripts read Joseph was recognized by his brothers
행 7:14 Then Joseph sent for his father, Jacob, and all his relatives to come to Egypt, seventy-five persons in all.
행 7:15 So Jacob went to Egypt. He died there, as did our ancestors.
행 7:16 Their bodies were taken to Shechem and buried in the tomb Abraham had bought for a certain price from Hamor's sons in Shechem.
행 7:17 "As the time drew near when God would fulfill his promise to Abraham, the number of our people in Egypt greatly increased.
행 7:18 But then a new king came to the throne of Egypt who knew nothing about Joseph.
행 7:19 This king exploited our people and oppressed them, forcing parents to abandon their newborn babies so they would die.
행 7:20 "At that time Moses was born?a beautiful child in God's eyes. His parents cared for him at home for three months.
행 7:21 When they had to abandon him, Pharaoh's daughter adopted him and raised him as her own son.
행 7:22 Moses was taught all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and he was powerful in both speech and action.
행 7:23 "One day when Moses was forty years old, he decided to visit his relatives, the people of Israel.
행 7:24 He saw an Egyptian mistreating an Israelite. So Moses came to the man's defense and avenged him, killing the Egyptian.
행 7:25 Moses assumed his fellow Israelites would realize that God had sent him to rescue them, but they didn't.
행 7:26 "The next day he visited them again and saw two men of Israel fighting. He tried to be a peacemaker. `Men,' he said, `you are brothers. Why are you fighting each other?'
행 7:27 "But the man in the wrong pushed Moses aside. `Who made you a ruler and judge over us?' he asked.
행 7:28 `Are you going to kill me as you killed that Egyptian yesterday?'
행 7:29 When Moses heard that, he fled the country and lived as a foreigner in the land of Midian. There his two sons were born.
행 7:30 "Forty years later, in the desert near Mount Sinai, an angel appeared to Moses in the flame of a burning bush.
행 7:31 When Moses saw it, he was amazed at the sight. As he went to take a closer look, the voice of the LORD called out to him,
행 7:32 `I am the God of your ancestors?the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.' Moses shook with terror and did not dare to look.
행 7:33 "Then the LORD said to him, `Take off your sandals, for you are standing on holy ground.
행 7:34 I have certainly seen the oppression of my people in Egypt. I have heard their groans and have come down to rescue them. Now go, for I am sending you back to Egypt.'① / ①Exod 3.5-10
행 7:35 "So God sent back the same man his people had previously rejected when they demanded, `Who made you a ruler and judge over us?' Through the angel who appeared to him in the burning bush, God sent Moses to be their ruler and savior.
행 7:36 And by means of many wonders and miraculous signs, he led them out of Egypt, through the Red Sea, and through the wilderness for forty years.
행 7:37 "Moses himself told the people of Israel, `God will raise up for you a Prophet like me from among your own people.'① / ①Deut 18.15
행 7:38 Moses was with our ancestors, the assembly of God's people in the wilderness, when the angel spoke to him at Mount Sinai. And there Moses received life-giving words to pass on to us①. / ①Some manuscripts read to you
행 7:39 "But our ancestors refused to listen to Moses. They rejected him and wanted to return to Egypt.
행 7:40 They told Aaron, `Make us some gods who can lead us, for we don't know what has become of this Moses, who brought us out of Egypt.'
행 7:41 So they made an idol shaped like a calf, and they sacrificed to it and celebrated over this thing they had made.
행 7:42 Then God turned away from them and abandoned them to serve the stars of heaven as their gods! In the book of the prophets it is written, `Was it to me you were bringing sacrifices and offerings during those forty years in the wilderness, Israel?

행 7:43 No, you carried your pagan gods? the shrine of Molech, the star of your god Rephan, and the images you made to worship them. So I will send you into exile as far away as Babylon.'① / ①Amos 5.25-27 (Greek version)
행 7:44 "Our ancestors carried the Tabernacle① with them through the wilderness. It was constructed according to the plan God had shown to Moses. / ①Greek the tent of witness
행 7:45 Years later, when Joshua led our ancestors in battle against the nations that God drove out of this land, the Tabernacle was taken with them into their new territory. And it stayed there until the time of King David.
행 7:46 "David found favor with God and asked for the privilege of building a permanent Temple for the God of Jacob①. / ①Some manuscripts read the house of Jacob
행 7:47 But it was Solomon who actually built it.
행 7:48 However, the Most High doesn't live in temples made by human hands. As the prophet says,
행 7:49 `Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool. Could you build me a temple as good as that?' asks the LORD. `Could you build me such a resting place?
행 7:50 Didn't my hands make both heaven and earth?'① / ①Isa 66.1-2
행 7:51 "You stubborn people! You are heathen① at heart and deaf to the truth. Must you forever resist the Holy Spirit? That's what your ancestors did, and so do you! / ①Greek uncircumcised
행 7:52 Name one prophet your ancestors didn't persecute! They even killed the ones who predicted the coming of the Righteous One?the Messiah whom you betrayed and murdered.
행 7:53 You deliberately disobeyed God's law, even though you received it from the hands of angels."
행 7:54 The Jewish leaders were infuriated by Stephen's accusation, and they shook their fists at him in rage①. / ①Greek they were grinding their teeth against him
행 7:55 But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, gazed steadily into heaven and saw the glory of God, and he saw Jesus standing in the place of honor at God's right hand.
행 7:56 And he told them, "Look, I see the heavens opened and the Son of Man standing in the place of honor at God's right hand!"
행 7:57 Then they put their hands over their ears and began shouting. They rushed at him
행 7:58 and dragged him out of the city and began to stone him. His accusers took off their coats and laid them at the feet of a young man named Saul①. / ①Saul is later called Paul; see 13.9
행 7:59 As they stoned him, Stephen prayed, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit."
행 7:60 He fell to his knees, shouting, "Lord, don't charge them with this sin!" And with that, he died.
행 8:1 Saul was one of the witnesses, and he agreed completely with the killing of Stephen. A great wave of persecution began that day, sweeping over the church in Jerusalem; and all the believers except the apostles were scattered through the regions of Judea and Samaria.
행 8:2 (Some devout men came and buried Stephen with great mourning.)
행 8:3 But Saul was going everywhere to destroy the church. He went from house to house, dragging out both men and women to throw them into prison.
행 8:4 But the believers who were scattered preached the Good News about Jesus wherever they went.
행 8:5 Philip, for example, went to the city of Samaria and told the people there about the Messiah.
행 8:6 Crowds listened intently to Philip because they were eager to hear his message and see the miraculous signs he did.
행 8:7 Many evil① spirits were cast out, screaming as they left their victims. And many who had been paralyzed or lame were healed. / ①Greek unclean
행 8:8 So there was great joy in that city.
행 8:9 A man named Simon had been a sorcerer there for many years, amazing the people of Samaria and claiming to be someone great.
행 8:10 Everyone, from the least to the greatest, often spoke of him as "the Great One?the Power of God."
행 8:11 They listened closely to him because for a long time he had astounded them with his magic.
행 8:12 But now the people believed Philip's message of Good News concerning the Kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ. As a result, many men and women were baptized.
행 8:13 Then Simon himself believed and was baptized. He began following Philip wherever he went, and he was amazed by the signs and great miracles Philip performed.
행 8:14 When the apostles in Jerusalem heard that the people of Samaria had accepted God's message, they sent Peter and John there.
행 8:15 As soon as they arrived, they prayed for these new believers to receive the Holy Spirit.
행 8:16 The Holy Spirit had not yet come upon any of them, for they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
행 8:17 Then Peter and John laid their hands upon these believers, and they received the Holy Spirit.

행 8:19 "Let me have this power, too," he exclaimed, "so that when I lay my hands on people, they will receive the Holy Spirit!"
행 8:20 But Peter replied, "May your money be destroyed with you for thinking God's gift can be bought!
행 8:21 You can have no part in this, for your heart is not right with God.
행 8:22 Repent of your wickedness and pray to the Lord. Perhaps he will forgive your evil thoughts,
행 8:23 for I can see that you are full of bitter jealousy and are held captive by sin."
행 8:24 "Pray to the Lord for me," Simon exclaimed, "that these terrible things you've said won't happen to me!"
행 8:25 After testifying and preaching the word of the Lord in Samaria, Peter and John returned to Jerusalem. And they stopped in many Samaritan villages along the way to preach the Good News.

행 8:27 So he started out, and he met the treasurer of Ethiopia, a eunuch of great authority under the Kandake, the queen of Ethiopia. The eunuch had gone to Jerusalem to worship,
행 8:28 and he was now returning. Seated in his carriage, he was reading aloud from the book of the prophet Isaiah.
행 8:29 The Holy Spirit said to Philip, "Go over and walk along beside the carriage."
행 8:30 Philip ran over and heard the man reading from the prophet Isaiah. Philip asked, "Do you understand what you are reading?"
행 8:31 The man replied, "How can I, unless someone instructs me?" And he urged Philip to come up into the carriage and sit with him.
행 8:32 The passage of Scripture he had been reading was this： "He was led like a sheep to the slaughter And as a lamb is silent before the shearers, he did not open his mouth.
행 8:33 He was humiliated and received no justice Who can speak of his descendants? For his life was taken from the earth."① / ①Isa 53.7-8 (Greek version)
행 8:34 The eunuch asked Philip, "Tell me, was the prophet talking about himself or someone else?"
행 8:35 So beginning with this same Scripture, Philip told him the Good News about Jesus.

행 8:37 ① / ①Some manuscripts add verse 37, "You can," Philip answered, "if you believe with all your heart." And the eunuch replied, "I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God."
행 8:38 He ordered the carriage to stop, and they went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
행 8:39 When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord snatched Philip away. The eunuch never saw him again but went on his way rejoicing.
행 8:40 Meanwhile, Philip found himself farther north at the town of Azotus. He preached the Good News there and in every town along the way until he came to Caesarea.
행 9:1 Meanwhile, Saul was uttering threats with every breath and was eager to kill the Lord's followers①. So he went to the high priest. / ①Greek disciples

행 9:3 As he was approaching Damascus on this mission, a light from heaven suddenly shone down around him.
행 9:4 He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, "Saul! Saul! Why are you persecuting me?"
행 9:5 "Who are you, lord?" Saul asked And the voice replied, "I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting!
행 9:6 Now get up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do."
행 9:7 The men with Saul stood speechless, for they heard the sound of someone's voice but saw no one!
행 9:8 Saul picked himself up off the ground, but when he opened his eyes he was blind. So his companions led him by the hand to Damascus.
행 9:9 He remained there blind for three days and did not eat or drink.
